Author: 13 March 2014
Review_Url: If you were to ask anybody, the likelihood of them telling you that they have never seen "The Wizard of Oz" is slim to none. As one of the most iconic films in American history, "The Wizard of Oz" is an enchanting film filled with laughter, music, and an intriguing story line that leaves you wanting to join Dorothy and the crew in the magical land of Oz.

Author: 30 August 2021
Review_Url: I simply adore this movie! So beautiful, love the music too!

Author: 14 January 2022
Review_Url: What's not to love? I grew up watching this as a child. I remember my brother and I getting excited every fall as they would start showing the previews. There's something to having to wait in anticipation - unlike today where we can have everything on demand - it makes you appreciate and value it more. We relished getting to see this every year.

Author: 31 December 2020
Review_Url: This movie amazes me. It amazes me that after 80+ years it is still as strong, magical and captivating as it must've been when it first came out. It amazes me how the tunes get stuck in my head, how they've truly permeated pop culture. It amazes me the technical feats they achieved that still hold weight today. Normally, I wouldn't give this a perfect score because I do thing there are some very very slight pacing issues and musical contrivances but the pure staying power of this has me bumping it up to the max.

Author: 6 January 2002
Review_Url: If ever there was a perfect film,this would be the one.I have loved this film since childhood,and it seems to get better with age.It contains wonderful special effects and cinematography, especially since film making was still in it's infancy at the time.The mixture of black and white and color is a very unique quality,adding more to the films appeal.Children may be a little frightened by the flying monkeys,as I was when I first saw them,so perhaps some parental discretion should be used if your young children are easily frightened.It definitely goes without saying that this is a great film,and,like fine wine,it only gets better with age.

Author: 13 November 2021
Review_Url: Wizard of Oz stacks up every year during the holidays. It is great fun and uplifting too.

Author: 16 February 2007
Review: Newly re-mastered print makes this better than ever.
Review_Url: We saw a re-mastered DVD print of this the other afternoon.

Author: 16 January 2023
Review: An Old School Masterpiece at work!
Review_Url: If there is a movie that I would consider to be the best movie of the 1930s, it would be this one! I would also say that this is the best movie with a tornado in it. Yes Tornados have been in other movies later on in time. But this... this is next level. The colors, music, and effects are beautiful as well! When my grandmother introduced me to this movie, I will admit that I was VERY impressed with it in the end. I always loved the music and the singing. Even though I'm more of an action themed movie goer, This movie is an acceptance. I hope that this movie will be fun to watch in the future! For all future generations to come!

Author: 23 July 2014
Review: Nostalgia...The Stuff Dreams Are Made Of
Review_Url: I have come across this film during the various stages of my life with the interpretation of Dorothy's travels changing each time. Maturity is a sobering catalyst of realism which often extinguishes the merriment of candy coated mountain tops and melting lemon drops. Nostalgia, however, is the last hope one has that connects them to that place somewhere over the rainbow. Watching this film as an adult sometimes creates a feeling of confounding dismay. Why can't I? Is the question I ask as I sit in the unemployment line or spit shine my useless, but nicely framed college degree. As I sit here broke, burdened and depressed by the tribulations of my adulthood, nostalgia finds its way into my gloomy existence offering a map to emerald city. How dare Dorothy lie to me, by igniting my ambitions as a child only to let me down in my adulthood. Is this the fault of Dorothy and her fellow conspirators or has the interpretation of her experience changed? I guess I will go with the latter since I know now that the place somewhere over the rainbow is still attainable, however, this place has a refurbished sense of meaning to me. This place exemplifies a spiritual paradise that can only be attained by faith. Here on earth, the daily grinds of life will always find a way to kill what little hope I have left, but money, credit cards, and SallieMae can never purchase the true feeling of spiritual freedom otherwise known to me as that place somewhere over the rainbow. I guess nostalgia has won me over yet again.

Author: 18 January 2014
Review: Is there a place where don't problems exist?
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is a film based on children's book by L. Frank Baum, produced by Metro-Goldyn-Mayer (MGM), 1939, U.S.A and directed by Vitor Flaming and George Cukor starring: Judy Garland, Frank Morgan, Ray Bolger, Jack Haley, and Bert Lahr. This fantastic film, tells the story of a girl named Dorothy (Judy Garland), who lives on a farm with her uncle Henry (Charley Grapeuwin) and aunt Em (Clara Blandick). The girl has a dog named Toto, and it bites Mrs. Gulch (Margareth Hamilton), Mrs. Gulch angry and with an authorization force Dorothy gives her dog, Mrs. Gulch takes the dog, but the dog escape and it come back for Dorothy's home. Dorothy is afraid that Mrs. Gulch takes her dog again and then she runs away from home, and in the middle of the road, she comes across a false clairvoyant, named Professor Marvel (Frank Morgan) who says he can sees present, past and future through of a crystal ball. He invites Dorothy to enter in his house and then he sees through of crystal ball that Dorothy's aunt is not going well. Dorothy desperate feels that her aunt is having a heart attack and she decides go home, but when she arrives in home, she doesn't find her uncles. Dorothy and her dog Toto are caught by a cyclone, and she sees everything running around: the house, Toto and her bed, and suddenly her house tumbles out in a colorful place where there are fairly tales, gnomes, scarecrows, tin man and a cowardly Lion, the place is the Land of Oz.

Author: 15 May 2019
Review_Url: I remember watching this movie when I was very young at my grandmothers house. I think the transition from black and white to color is absolutely fantastic. Judy Garland is a perfect Dorothy and how cute is Toto? I thought it was pretty cool that all these other character Dorothy encounters on her journey are down to help. This movie is and forever will be iconic.

Author: 22 June 2006
Review: the best movie that i have ever seen.
Review_Url: OK.... who does not like the Wizrad of oz.... i mean... come on... that is probably one of the best movies that i have ever seen. in fact that is the best movie that i have ever seen. i am probably the only twelve year old girl that is almost obbsessed with that movie. well... there are other twelve yeard old girls that love that movie, so i guess i am one of the twelve year old girls that is almost obbsessed with the wizard of oz. i guess that comes to show you that no matter how old you are you can still love a movie that is almost 60 years older than you are. i think the thing that made the wizard of oz so successful is that back then movies were made in black and white. in this movie it was made in black and white plus color. i like the fact that when dorathy was in kansas the director made it black and white... but when she was in oz the director made it in color... if it was in all black and white i would have gotten really bored even though the plot of the story is amazing. plus the actors were absolutely amazing... i couldn't imagine any one else playing those parts. in credible movie and i think who ever hasn't seen it to go out and see it... it is an ingredible movie.

Author: 11 April 2019
Review: This movie is a classic...there is nothing more to say!
Review_Url: I re-watched this movie because I was so young the last time I saw it. The choreography, the singing, the dancing all great! Judy Garland is great as Dorothy and Margaret Hamilton is great as the Wicked Witch of the West. The fact that The Wicked Witch of the West still kind of freaks me out a little shows how good of an actress Margaret Hamilton was. The way the movie is in black and white at the beginning and then it changes to this beautiful color is superb. This movie was made in 1939 so it is way ahead of its time!!! There is nothing more to say.....it is excellent!!!

Author: 1 October 2006
Review: Overcoming One's Own Character Limitations is a Daunting Task
Review_Url: Overcoming one's own character limitations in youth is a necessary but a daunting task. Those who resign themselves to the safe harbor of postponing efforts to take on risks and challenges have their character development set in time. The characters in the movie, the cowardly lion, the heartless tin man, and brainless scarecrow all symbolize the character flaws in Dorothy's real life adult friends back home. To some degree, Dorothy collectively had each one of those flaws. We see in Dorothy an intelligence, courageous, and a good-hearted young lady. When Dorothy suffers a concussion and drifts into a coma, she mentally commits herself to overcoming those flaws. A mental challenge known as the trip down the "yellow brick road." Her initial expectation was to painlessly be cured by Wizard of Oz and sent home. The Wizard, however, prescribed an arduous journey that would put to test all her capacities. She would have to confront evil in the world, in the form of the Wicked Witch of the West. From her trial and tribulations would emerge her renewed self. In the process, she would show care, compassion, and a deep concern for her companion's safety and well-being over her own. It was Dorothy's final act of forgiveness and concern towards one who would do her harm that would put her over the threshold.

Author: 22 January 2015
Review_Url: "The Wizard of Oz" is a delightful movie for children. Adults can enjoy it too, provided they don't spend any time thinking about it.

Author: 9 April 2022
Review_Url: I will never say "we don't make films like this anymore". No. I believe that we do and - thanks to a bigger industry, more professionals, the technologial advance - I even think that we do in much more quantity than before. What I can't also say is that very good films are just a product of our time and were created in a vacuum.

Author: 31 October 2020
Review: Movie Review: HIST of American Cinema 272
Review_Url: "The Wizard of Oz", directed by Victor Fleming, is a classic and all time favorite film for many people. What made this such a great film is the use of imagination and the friendships between the characters. Another amazing thing about this movie was the cinematography. There were lots of great shots with special effects used to highlight the magical moments in the scenes. A lot of the characters had very enthusiastic and vibrant personalities to them which I think makes them more enjoyable and relatable. I also think the way the characters were written had a huge influence on future stories and movies. In most films and television shows, the evil/villain character always has the same type of high pitched evil sounding cackle, and I think this came from the Wicked Witch of The West. Another great aspect of this movie is the way Fleming weaved all the musical numbers throughout the story. I think each song came into place at the right time and nothing seemed out of place.

Author: 7 February 2022
Review: A timeless classic that every cinephile NEEDS to see!
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz showed that Technicolor was becoming a booming phenomenon in Hollywood, that fantasy storytelling was becoming a seriously-taken form of art and escapism, and Judy Garland became a household name for all-time; and I didn't even mention 'Somewhere Over The Rainbow' yet. This film is a classic that EVERYONE deserves to see, especially if they claim to be a cinema lover.

Author: 15 September 2020
Review: Pay no attention to that man behind the curtain!
Review_Url: "The Wizard of Oz" regales us with a colourful, grandiose adaptation of the enduring L. Frank Baum story, albeit sanitized a bit to better suit a family audience. Young Dorothy Gale (Judy Garland) gets caught in a frightening tornado that ends up transporting her to a magical land. It's a land populated by singing "Munchkins", good and evil witches, flying monkeys, and a trio containing three of the best friends that Dorothy could hope to have. The Scarecrow (Ray Bolger), who only wants a brain, The Tin Man (Jack Haley), who only wants a heart, and The Cowardly Lion (Bert Lahr), who desires courage. They will embark on a quest down a Yellow Brick Road to meet with an all-powerful Wizard (Frank Morgan) who can supposedly grant their wishes. Standing in their way is the nasty Wicked Witch of the West (Margaret Hamilton).

Review: One of my best childhood memories
Review_Url: This is the one of my best childhood memories about movies that I'll remember forever.

Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz was made in 1939, i did like this movie. i never knew that now this movie is so old. I enjoyed ever moment of this movie. I liked the part where they followed the yellow brick road. I give this movie 10 out of 10.

Author: 5 January 2001
Review: I tried to hate it, really i did (spoilers)
Review_Url: Don't touch me.  I'm a hideous, hideous freak.  Somehow, I managed to live for twenty-two years without seeing The Wizard of Oz.

Author: 6 January 2021
Review_Url: Considering the longevity of this film's popularity, I feel it would be pointless going into detail about its plot, so I will be constructing my review based entirely on my opinion of it. Quite simply, it is a classic, both wonderfully written and performed.

Author: 24 October 2007
Review_Url: My 14th review for IMDb will be by far the easiest one I'll ever write. "The Wizard of Oz is a timeless classic that has endured for 68 years (as of 2007), and will undoubtedly continue to live in people's hearts long after you, the dear reader, ceases to live. To point out a flaw in this film is the equivalent of finding a flaw in the Mona Lisa: you just can't. And even if you do, you'll never be able to shake off your enduring memories of it.

Author: 31 March 2021
Review_Url: This was one of the earliest movies I remember watching with my mom; I even remember Dorothy being one of my first Halloween costumes. I loved how the movie starts off in black and white and turns into vibrant colors once Dorothy is asleep, which allows the viewer to put a clear distinction between Dorothy's real life and her subconscious, even invoking a feeling of sadness that to Dorothy, her life seemed dull and in need of life. The part I loved the most was that Dorothy befriended the characters of Oz, despite some of them not showing her kindness initially. Dorothy was the true light in her dark world, and it's bittersweet to see the realization of her true worth once she wakes up. This movie will forever live in the fondest part of heart. A true classic.

Author: 3 December 2020
Review_Url: When I was little, I would literally watch this movie more than 1,000,000 times. I would literally watch this movie every single day, & it would drive my brother crazy. Every second of it was amazing.

Author: 30 August 2020
Review: Magnificent no matter how many times it's been see before!
Review_Url: A Kansas farm girl and her dog are in trouble. She tries to run away, gets swept into the magical but frightening land of Oz only to learn there's no place like home.

Author: 17 January 2011
Review_Url: What more needs to be said about a film that has gone beyond the status of a mere classic to become an enduring part of our national heritage? Is there anyone alive unfamiliar with Dorothy or Toto or the tornado or the Munchkins or the Yellow Brick Road or the Scarecrow, the Tin Man, the Cowardly Lion, the Wicked Witch of the West, the Emerald City, the Great and Powerful Oz, the ruby slippers, or the fact that there's no place like home?

Author: 5 February 2015
Review_Url: Rating-7/10

Author: 12 January 2010
Review_Url: Michael Crichton wrote in his 1987 novel Sphere that whereas Greek mythology was "common knowledge" in ancient times, today there are educated people who do not know it. Is it that we have abandoned myth altogether? Maybe not- he goes on to write "Perhaps these are our new myths. Dorothy and Toto and the Wicked Witch..." The Wizard of Oz, the classic 1939 movie, attempts to bring a modern-day, American-made mythology to life. And there's no doubt it succeeded. The film has reached legendary status, to the point where others have referenced it- Oz references appear in various places in my DVD collection, from Arrested Development to Futurama, and from The Simpsons to Gremlins 2.

Author: 13 April 2011
Review_Url: I don't know what is the main genre for this movie: musical, family or fantasy movie. It has a bit of everything and succeeds in every aspect. Yes the story is simple and there isn't that much action but I don't think a movie needs to be scary or have violence to be entertaining. Despite being made pre World War II this movie is magical. What makes the movie really enjoyable are its colorful characters who take you onto a journey with catchy songs. Although Judy Garland was story-wise too old to play Dorothy, I don't think anyone else could have done it better here. Her song "Somewhere over the rainbow" is still a very recognizable and loved song today. That this movie still stands strong without CGI or expensive decor is an amazing feat. Maybe not a movie I would watch that often but when I do I will love every minute of it.

Author: 11 April 2006
Review_Url: "We're off to see the Wizard, The Wonderful Wizard of Oz..."

Author: 19 July 2005
Review: A modern day classic of film and cherished masterpiece
Review_Url: I cannot wait for that magic 100 year anniversary of this fantastic film. I have cherished this movie since I was little and at 16 the magic still hasn't and I don't think ever will fade. This movie, like they say, truly is the world's modern day fairy-tale that everybody can relate to, in a sense, and if the movie's star score " Over The Rainbow" don't invoke some goosebumps or any form of touching emotionally, then I pity you. I have always loved the movie and grown with it over the years, going from being terrified of the Wicked Witch of The West and her flying monkeys, and being happily entertained by the Cowardly Lion's slapstick, to being enchanted as I got older by Judy Garland's voice and the main story, which, in reference to the book, is extremely flawed and shortened by one third of what is actually done, but that is okay for it was based on a stage production of the show, which today it still runs as school programs, and I saw one that gave a spectacle, treating audience members to the dated, but extremely infectious " The Jitterbug" a deleted song, to the heartstring pulling reprise of " Over The Rainbow" when Dorthy is captured within the confines of the witches castle, but is unable to finish and burst into tears, but nevertheless, the movie is a standard and is something that I will never tie of, and until a remake that can honor the glory of such a wonderful movie, I can't think of a movie that can match it's magic!

Author: 20 August 2005
Review: OZ: A Grown Up's Movie That Kids Enjoy
Review_Url: THE WIZARD OF OZ is a paradox: although made with a juvenile audience in mind, the completed film has an unexpectedly adult sensibility, and children enjoy it on one level while adults find it a considerably more complex experience. Like most fairy tales, OZ deals in archetypes--but instead of merely referencing them, OZ specifies them in a uniquely literal way and transforms them into a brilliantly beautiful yet extremely menacing tale of innocence lost. It is a surprisingly psychological film, and any one foolish enough to scratch its surface will soon find themselves dealing with more "isms" than a roomful of research psychiatrists could explain.

Author: 24 May 2021
Review_Url: It's no wonder, audiences had a hard time in the early 1900s, enjoying the previous incarnations of the Wizard of Oz. Released in theaters as early as 1910, audiences wanted more from these early attempts. They wanted more, than just guys in bad horse costumes, cheezie bat costumes and effects, that even audiences in 1914 felt, did not look good. The film industry was not ready for the kind of storytelling, that L. Frank Baum needed to have, in order to make these films appealing to the audience of the day. These types of films needed more time to pass. They needed Hollywood to evolve and grow more. They needed to wait until 1939.

Author: 18 November 2021
Review_Url: I heard alot about this movie and today I finally watched it. What to say, I didn't expect that I will like this movie too much. I enjoyed every single part of it. You can't take out any mistake in this movie. The performances by the actors, visuals, direction, writing, cinematography, music, sound effects .... you name it, everything was perfect.

Author: 19 January 2014
Review: Welcome to the land of Fantasy
Review_Url: It was 1939, when "Gone with the Wind" took the major awards of Oscar. But, that's another movie that also made a history of the cinema, yes, this movie. Full of fantasy, that very surprising in its era. I haven't watch "Gone with the Wind" yet, but this movie just make me believe the magic of 1939. I think the revolution of the movie and also new standard of the film-idea itself. There are no border in the movie, you can make a world whatever you want, that's what "The Wizard of Oz" tried to make.

Author: 20 October 2017
Review_Url: A classic from another era! I remember, as a child, watching The Wizard of Oz at least once a year. A great cast. Judy Garland's plays the great innocent girl. There is no place like home is a memorable line. The character's the cowardly lion, tin man, and scarecrow are memorable. A great fantasy with a villain the witch of the west. I will get your little dog too says it all. Having to find the Wizard who is the reluctant Hero creates the home away form home back to home story. The Star Wars of the 40's era film. My sister told me that half the film got burned and The Wizard of Oz middle was filmed in color. Begins in black and white, middle is color, and end in black and white adds a neat effect of a never world. Never get stuck in a tornado or you could end up in Oz. Let's not for get the little dog Totto was a great little extra for a film that added many great details for a classic film. Nine out of 10 stars.

Author: 19 July 2006
Review: The greatest movie of all time
Review_Url: Almost all 6.5 billion people in the world have heard of this film. Where a young girl and her dog are transported into a fantastical, magical land of munchkins and fairies and... The Wicked Witch of The West.

Author: 26 August 2005
Review: One of Judy Garland's best performances.
Review_Url: One of the best movies ever. Judy Garland deservedly won a Special 1939 Academy Award (the only time she ever won an Oscar) for her performance as Dorothy. Filled with great songs such as "Over the Rainbow" and "Ding-Dong, the Witch is Dead." Bert Lahr is hilarious as the Cowardly Lion ("Put 'em up, Put 'em up!). Excellent direction by Victor Fleming (Gone With The Wind), great costumes and sets, and a well-written script, which is based on the book by L.Frank Baum. The movie is even better seen on the big screen. The characters are brought to life by amazing performances (which includes Frank Morgan in 5 roles). "Oz" is a film to watch over and over. Recommended. 10/10.

Author: 5 March 1999
Review: Seek a fine print of this film
Review_Url: One of the joys of seeing "The Wizard of Oz" is viewing a pristine print. Over the years the extraordinary Technicolor original quality has been diminished due to old prints, which have long lost their bloom. Seeing a print as close to the original as possible is a unique film experience. Not a restored version, mind you, but one cast from the original negative.

Author: 28 October 2007
Review: Very gorgeous and beautiful - but is it the best?
Review_Url: People have described this film as captivating, the best, most charming film they have ever seen. For some people there are a great deal many films they would prefer, but with no doubt it is likely every person will like this a wee bit in some wee way!

Author: 14 May 2019
Review_Url:
Dorothy Gale lives with her dog Toto on the Kansas farm of her Aunt Em and Uncle Henry. Toto bites Miss Almira Gulch on the leg, and she obtains an order from the sheriff for Toto to be euthanized. She takes Toto away on her bicycle, but he escapes and returns to Dorothy, and she decides to run away. She meets Professor Marvel, a kindly fortune teller who uses his crystal ball to make Dorothy believe that Aunt Em may be dying of a broken heart. Dorothy races home, arriving just as a tornado strikes. Locked out of the farm's storm cellar, she seeks shelter in her bedroom. Wind-blown debris knocks her unconscious and the house is sent spinning in the air. She awakens to see various figures fly by, including Miss Gulch on her bicycle, who transforms into a witch on a broomstick.The house lands in Munchkinland in the Land of Oz. Glinda the Good Witch of the North and the Munchkins welcome her as a heroine, as the falling house has killed the Wicked Witch of the East. Her sister, the Wicked Witch of the West, arrives to claim the slippers, but Glinda transports them onto Dorothy's feet first. The Wicked Witch of the West swears revenge on Dorothy, then vanishes. Glinda tells Dorothy to keep the slippers on and follow the yellow brick road to the Emerald City, where she can ask the Wizard of Oz to help her get back home.
On her journey, Dorothy meets the Scarecrow, who wants a brain, the Tin Woodman, who desires a heart, and the Cowardly Lion, who needs courage. Dorothy invites them to accompany her to Emerald City, where they can ask the Wizard to help them too. Despite the Witch's attempts to foil their journey, they reach the Emerald City and are eventually permitted to see the Wizard, who appears as a large ghostly head surrounded by fire and smoke. He agrees to grant their wishes if they prove their worth by bringing him the Witch's broomstick.
As the foursome and Toto make their way to the Witch's castle, the Witch captures Dorothy and plots her death in order to remove her slippers. Toto escapes and leads her three friends to the castle. They ambush three guards, don the guards' uniforms, march inside and free Dorothy. The Witch and her guards chase and surround them. The Witch sets fire to the Scarecrow, causing Dorothy to toss a bucket of water, inadvertently splashing the Witch, who melts away. The guards rejoice and give Dorothy her broomstick.The Wizard stalls in fulfilling his promises, until Toto pulls back a curtain and exposes the "Wizard" as a middle-aged man operating machinery and speaking into a microphone. Admitting to being a humbug, he insists that he is a good man but a bad wizard. He then gives the Scarecrow a diploma, the Lion a medal and the Tin Man a ticking heart-shaped watch, helping them see that the attributes they sought were already within them. He then offers to take Dorothy and Toto home in his hot air balloon. He reveals that he, too, is from Kansas, and worked at a carnival when a tornado brought him to the Emerald City. He was offered and accepted the job as Wizard due to hard times.
As Dorothy and the Wizard prepare to depart, Toto, distracted by a cat, leaps from Dorothy's arms. As she pursues Toto, the balloon disembarks with the Wizard, leaving Dorothy. Glinda appears and tells Dorothy the ruby slippers have the power to return her to Kansas if she taps her heels together three times repeating "There's no place like home." Dorothy complies and wakes up in her bedroom surrounded by her family and friends, including Toto. Everyone dismisses her adventure as a dream, but Dorothy insists it was real and says she will never run away from home again. She then declares: "There's no place like home!"

Author: 27 September 2006
Review_Url: "The Wizard of Oz" is probably one of the five most popular movies ever, along with "Gone with the wind", "Casablanca", etc. It was a technical revolution (one of the first color movies) and everyone agrees that it's sickly sweet and sentimental and that there is not a character more affected than Dorothy Gale... Whatever, the colours, all those mythical scenes, "Over the rainbow"... It's a classic and that's that! I don't like musicals, I've never understood those movies in which the characters begin to sing with no reason, but "Wizard of Oz" is an exception, as well as "Willy Wonka" or "The Rocky Horror Picture ShoW"

Author: 27 June 2007
Review: Easily, one of the 10 top movie productions!!
Review_Url: Easily, in the 10 top movie productions!! One of the few films that the entire Family can enjoy. It didn't need any animation or the overkill of today's special effects to be totally entertaining. And yes, no one needed to spout out those 4 letter words that in todays world are somehow mandatory for good acting & film-making. And what a wonderful idea. Start the film in black & white. Then, when landing in OZ, they used a most effective technique of switching to color as the house door is opened for a first peak outside. Also, credit the gifted supporting actors, whose characters played so well against each others personalities and obvious shortcomings. The simple innocence of the Dorothy character bolstered by the incredible musical talents of Judy Garland made the film an all time classic. Many of the really great films were made during the 30's & 40's. And no, I didn't live during those times.

Author: 2 August 2006
Review_Url: I first saw this film when my grandmother bought me the 50th anniversary addition of when i was too young to recall my own age. I grew up watching this film on an almost daily basis until i was at least 10 years old. i never got tired of it and i always found it inspiring to a boy who needed to be inspired like me at that time. this films magical portrayal of the inner child in all of us brought out of the best in me at that time. knowing full well how your friends can make a difference for you. and not to mention that most this film has a message for more than just children...but for the young in heart in all of us.

Author: 6 August 2013
Review: A classic movie that brings the imagination of childhood.
Review_Url: It's probably a shame for me to have watched this movie too late, but since it's a classic, I don't feel bad about that.

Author: 19 October 2016
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is a mesmerizing tale that takes viewers to an enchanted land beyond their wildest imaginations. It's a land filled with bright colors, memorable music, and a wicked old witch, played by Margaret Hamilton. Dorothy Gale, played by the incomparable Judy Garland, gets whisked away from her farm in Kansas to a magical land called Oz. After learning that her house killed the Wicked Witch of the East, a group of jolly munchkins points her in the direction of the Emerald City along the yellow brick road. While she and her dog Toto are traveling this road, she meets and befriends a witless scarecrow (Ray Bolger), a rusty tin man (Jack Haley), and a cowardly lion (Burt Lahr). The four friends then embark on a journey to see "the wonderful Wizard of Oz (Frank Morgan)" in the Emerald City. This is a perfect movie for children of all ages and their families to enjoy. But beware, some scenes might be a little scary for younger children, such as the ones with the Wicked Witch of the West. However, the movie incorporates many funny and enjoyable scenes. The combination of these different scenes makes the movie especially entertaining. Writers Noel Langley, Florence Ryerson, Edgar Allan Woolf, did a spectacular job adapting the movie from the book. The acting is superb by each and every one of the characters. You can tell that the actors and actresses became one with their characters, making it really believable for the audience. Adrian Adolph Greenberg did a wonderful job with the costumes. The makeup was also very well done, giving the impression that characters such as the Scarecrow, were real people. The costumes and makeup were imaginative, adding to the overall magic of the movie. The setting and props did an excellent job of making Oz seem like a real place. The special effects helped add even more to the realism of Oz. My absolute favorite thing about the movie was the marvelous singing and dancing. The music is catchy, and makes you feel like you want to sing along. The dancing goes especially well with the songs and was amusing to watch. All in all, The Wizard of Oz is unforgettable story, sure to be a hit for years to come. It's a movie you can watch over and over again and it never loses its magic. I know I'm definitely going to add it to my list of favorite movies. So be sure to watch it with your family and friends, I can promise you that you won't regret it.

Author: 18 June 2021
Review_Url: Great movie I really enjoyed watching the movie, the songs in the movie were great especially the song we're off to see the wizard, I liked the main characters in the movie, they were all fun, the movie didn't lose its magic even after all these years, I recommend watching it.

Review_Url: I am an adaptation of the popular novel first saw when I was 10 years old. THE WIZARD of OZ has left a mark. Author: 12 May 2006
Review: Masterpieces Of Technicolor: The Wizard Of Oz
Review_Url: The Wizard Of Oz (1939): Starring Judy Garland, Ray Bolger, Jack Haley, Bert Lahr, Margaret Hamilton, Billie Burke, Frank Morgan, Clara Blandick, Charlie Grapewin, Pat Walsh, Charles Becker...Director Victor Fleming, Screenplay Noel Langley Released in 1939, "The Wizard Of Oz" was not the only film of that time to be presented in the new cinematic Technicolor. "Gone With The Wind", which swept the Oscars that year, was also a masterpiece of Technicolor, and like this film, a classic of America cinema. There is much to admire in "Wizard Of Oz", which has taken its place in cinematic history as America's most beloved family classic. Drawn from the novel by L. Frank Baum, this was not the first version to appear in film. Dramatic silent film renditions were made between 1910-1914 "The Wizard Of Oz" and "His Majesty, The Scarecrow Of Oz" based on the Baum novels. But this was a phenomenal musical version, starring Judy Garland in a signature role. She portrays Dorothy Gayle, a girl from Kansas who lives with her Aut Em and Uncle Henry and seems to have a difficult time fitting in. Before long, a tornado whisks her away to an enchanted world of elfin creatures called Munchkins and a beautiful enchantress Glinda (Billie Burke) who tell her that the only way out is through an audience with the mysterious Wizard of the Emerald City. Dorothy and her dog Toto start down the Yellow Brick Road and encounter a trio of characters which have become household names - The Scarecrow (Ray Bolger), The Tin Man (Jack Haley) and The Cowardly Lion (Bert Lahr). The Wicked Witch of the West (Margaret Hamilton in a terrific performance) is after Dorothy, hell-bent on killing her and retrieving the powerful ruby slippers. The unforgettable songs like Follow The Yellow Brick Road, Somewhere Over The Rainbow by Harold Arlen became top American songs of the 20th century. This film is pure magic, unlike anything of its time. When Dorothy leaves behind the dull, black-and-white world of Kansas, audiences are literally transported from the earlier black-and-white films of the 20's and 30's to the new and vibrant world of Technicolor, which is Oz. This film not only represents the Golden Age of early Technicolor cinema, but it is a story that has a powerful theme of returning to one's home, of finding one's identity. Dorothy, far from being a flat character, journeys from awkward, flighty girl to courageous, mature young woman who has acquired a sense of self and, whether we believe she dreamed Oz or lived it, she can now live her life with a renewed sense of confidence. This movie can never go out of style. It remains a classic of American cinema. Enjoy!

Author: 17 January 2021
Review_Url: What a great movie for kids. A 30 year old teenager from Kansas has a dog to be executed, and rightfully so, for biting old ladies in their own gardens, but the dog escapes and comes home, so naturally Dorothy decides to run away from home and meets a gypsy who unrealistically helps to convince her to go home instead of take advantage of her, and that's why a tornado begins and Dorothy runs home just in-time to see all her family and friends are saving their own lives in a shelter instead of looking for her. Soon Dorothy is knocked unconscious and wakes up to watch a movie outside her window and realises her house is inside the tornado, but amazingly in one peice!

Author: 30 June 2020
Review_Url:
The Wizard of Oz was a technical and visual marvel when it was first released in 1939, pushing the boundaries of what could be accomplished on film. Despite numerous behind-the-scenes issues that marred the production, it was a film that wowed the world and propelled Judy Garland into superstardom and an infamy that would be viewed simultaneous to her name years and years after her passing.
Now, in 2020, The Wizard of Oz is every bit as fresh, entertaining and moving as it was the day it first came out. Judy's stellar performance of Over the Rainbow never fails to bring tears, Margaret Hamilton's deliciously malicious cackles still terrify, and Frank Morgan's Emerald City is still as pretty as it ever was before.
With the help of Warner Bros.' fantastic 4K transfer, The Wizard of Oz looks even nicer, bringing out the absolute best the original nitrate negatives had to offer, bringing us closer to what Oz looked like on set than we've ever been before.

Author: 21 March 2013
Review: "If happy little bluebirds fly beyond the rainbow, why oh why cant I?"
Review_Url: This film is one of the most quintessential classics of cinema. Chances are that you've seen it aired every Thanksgiving, or you've seen clips of it all over the place, of you've heard the songs sung and resung, or you've seen parodies. The Wizard of Oz has become so ingrained in American culture that the film, its scenes, its characters, its music, its dialogue, and just about everything is instantly recognizable and endearing.

Author: 30 November 2012
Review: Judy brings magic on every step
Review_Url: The wizard of Oz is a colorful classic, that is filled with thrills and it is a straight shooter right from the start to the very end. From following the yellow brick road to finally meeting the wizard himself, it was a bumpy ride that I always look forward to going again.

Author: 11 January 2007
Review: One of the three greatest movies ever made.
Review_Url: A Beautiful Mind, Cassablanca, and THIS ... The Wizard of Oz. Every cast member perfect in their respective role(s). The photography, the use of sepia tone and then wonderful colour, the music, the songs and choreography, the sets and costumes, the makeup, the wonderful plot, all things perfectly handled and unsurpassed. The lion starts to roar at the beginning of this thing and I start to get all blubbery. My only wish is that the Jitter Bug sequence be available. That wonderful part that was cut out due to length and time and left to rot as worthless celluloid on the cutting room floor. ~sigh~ Oh well. There has never been, and there will never be, another movie like this one.This movie, this work of art, is so comfortable that to go to Oz with Dorothy is just like going home, sweet, home. And, as you know, there's no place like home.

Author: 31 March 2014
Review: We're off to see the wizard
Review_Url: What a great movie I think more people have seen The Wizard of Oz, then an movie in cinema history. I remember seeing this as a kid and it never got old to me. Sometimes you watch a movie and you may forget about the characters, or different scenes but not this one. This film also became a musical on Broadway, that's how beloved it was. We forget about the little songs we learned growing up like," We're off to see the Wizard the wonderful Wizard of OZ". The film was so colorful from the background to the characters, the only thing that was dark was the witch and wizard. The lion, the tin man,the straw man, Toto, and Judy Garland as Dorothy from themselves walking on the yellow brick road to see the wizard.The imagery was absolutely magnificent, and you can't forget about the effect of the house spinning and lifting off the ground.

Author: 4 September 2021
Review_Url: While this was not the first iteration of The Wizard of Oz that I have seen, it certainly was nice to see where it originated from. Though it has a simple plot, it is old but gold, with many heart warming moral of the story. Though some parts of the film were a little odd and unnerving, given that this film was made at a time where this kind of films were very much at its infancy, it really isn't much I can complain about. It is not so much as a deal breaker but more like something to take note of. However I do believe that this is a film that would significantly cater to the tastes of some people. Unfortunately that is not mine, but I can still see that it is a good film and one that I believe everyone should watch at least once, if not for the story, then for the exposure of how monumental this film was for the industry.

Author: 14 May 2020
Review_Url:
This is an incredible movie....
The colour is super saturated because they actually shot on 3 movie cameras 1 producing a Red image, 1 producing a Blue and the last producing a Green image then overlayed them all...(yeah I know it's more complicated than that but hey..)
Then there's the make up, the silver they put on the Tin Man was toxic as was the Green on the Witch..the Tin Man actor had to be replaced as it was so bad (he had to be placed in an Iron Lung) and both the new actor and the Witch became ill during production...the Witch caught on fire when one of the pyrotechnic explosions went wrong..then the flying monkeys injured themselves when the flying wires broke...Toto the dogs paw was broken when it got stepped on....oh and the Snow is asbestos!!!!!!
Regardless of all the behind the scenes shenanigans, its an incredible piece of art, basically a long Stage Play filmed..it's still great to this day..

Author: 8 October 2020
Review_Url: This is a special movie that requires an in-depth analysis. After a thorough research I found that the book "The Wonderful Wizard of Oz", which the film is based on, was declared "America's greatest and best-loved homegrown fairytale" by the Library of Congress. This charming story really merits it. Therefore, the contribution of the author L.Frank Baum deserves recognition.

Author: 5 June 2010
Review_Url: No matter who you talk to, chances are they have at least heard of this movie or the play that it was adapted from. This was one of the most successful movies of the decade especially due to its elaborate sets and costumes, which were very convincing for the year it was made. This was also Judy Garland's first major film, and it caught many producer's attentions to get her more work and cement her as one of the greatest actresses/singers of the 20th century.

Review_Url: What can be said about one of the most quoted movies of all time, the simply wonderful fantasy film about a girl who after a horrible tornado is whirled away to the magical world of OZ, where she encounters magical characters of all kinds, a scarecrow, a tin man, and a cowardly lion, all of whom seek something from the magical wizard the most mysterious man in OZ, so they go on a journey to kill the evil wicked witch so the girl can be sent home. its a wonderful adventure

Author: 7 November 2017
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is an all time classic and a complete masterpiece. I've probably watched this movie over 100 times. It was and still is my favorite growing up. I was obsessed with Dorothy and Toto, and terrified of the Wicked Witch of the West. I absolutely love the way they filmed this masterpiece. The transition from black and white to beautiful colors was unique and different which made the movie so special. Even in present times, most people know about the Wizard of Oz and they still have musicals for it. If you haven't seen it, or your kids haven't seen it, I strongly recommend this movie to anyone at any age. The scarecrow and the cowardly lion are hilarious. The colors and the scenery was amazingly put together. One of my most favorite scenes of the movie is when they all fall asleep in the poppy field and get woken up by snow. Everything about that scene was beautiful, even the music.

Author: 11 April 2018
Review_Url: Who doesn't have fond memories of watching The Wizard of Oz at some point in their lives, young or old? It still holds up beautifully after all these years. Wonderful and immersive cinematography, likable and memorable characters, and absolutely beautiful colors. The fact that not only a film this old is still known this well today, but that it's still just as beloved as when it first came out (if not even more) is amazing. I can only imagine what the audience thought back then when they first saw it. A movie literally everyone should see.

Author: 21 October 2020
Review_Url: The Wizard of oz was way before its time and is still an amazing story. Basically a girl name Dorothy and her dog todo get swept up inside a tornado in Kansas and brings them into the magical land of Oz. While they were transported they accident my land and kill the Wicked Witch of the East. She ends up following the yellow brick road to go see the wizard of Oz to wish to go back home. On her way down the road she bumps into and meets 3 characters being a Scarecrow, Tin man, and a Lion. They all agree to join her down the yellow brick road in hopes for their own wishes to be granted. The scarecrow wants a brain, the tin man wants a heart and the lion wants courage. The wicked witch of the war finds out that they killed her sister and is on a hunt to kill them. The group face multiple obstacles and finally end up going to Emerald City to see the wizard. The wizard turns out to not be a real one but a fraud. The group ends up killing the Witch and getting their wishes granted. The Good witch tells Dorothy she could've gone home at any time as long as she tapped her shoes 3 times. Dorothy says her goodbyes and leaves. Dorothy learns a lot of lessons during this time and I believe it's a great movie that sparked a whole genre of film. It's a classic and will forever be one of my top movies. Highly recommended.

Author: 7 May 2014
Review: A Magical Movie That is Still Cherished Today
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz (1939) directed by Mervyn Leroy, is a fun movie that is simply unforgettable. This film has iconic set pieces, and bright colors, which is amazing for the time it was made. The film starts out black and white, but progresses to color upon arrival at Oz. The characters in the film are all great, and the relationships between the characters is heartwarming. The music in the film is great and the band of friends skipping down the yellow brick road is iconic and simply innocent. The movie has some macabre elements and themes, but they do not make up the vast majority of the films feel. Overall, The Wizard of Oz (1939) is an outstanding piece of filmmaking worthy of a 9 out of 10.

Author: 28 September 2020
Review: We're off to see the wizard.
Review_Url: This technicolour triumph tells the time-old tale of Dorothy, a young girl who gets whisked away to the magical land of Oz and must find a way back to Kansas with some help from a few friends she picks up along the way. 'The Wizard Of Oz (1939)' is a colourful, quite energetic musical that's as iconic as they come, practically etched into the memory of every cinema-loving person regardless of if they've seen it all the way through or not. The flick has some legitimately entertaining sequences and its aesthetic really is distinct, brought to life with stellar set-design and creative costuming that almost pops off the screen. It does sag a little in its mid-section and it isn't exactly complex when it comes to its themes. In a way, its story is a little too straightforward. Plus, its sanded edges make for a somewhat 'vanilla' experience. Still, the picture is mostly enjoyable and is practically the definition of escapist fantasy. 6/10

Author: 27 August 2014
Review: Has a good message underneath the darker stuff.
Review_Url: On the surface, The Wizard of Oz is a very dark and twisted tale. Dorothy the protagonist lives in the country, surrounded by corruption (for example, a mean-spirited local woman has relatives in high places, thanks to which she easily gets the local judge to sign off on an order to put down Dorothy's adorable dog Toto), crime (when Dorothy runs off to save Toto, she doesn't get more than a few miles from her house before coming across a vagrant who tries to rob her, and would've probably tried worse if the weather hadn't suddenly kicked up), and frequent natural disasters in the form of twister tornadoes. It's pretty much Hell on Earth, and it's no wonder that Dorothy is desperate to leave this dreadful place, to which effect she sings a very moving song in the beginning.

Author: 18 February 2006
Review: Frankie Dee Brown omitted as a black munchkin
Review_Url: My dad told me that Frankie Dee Brown played in this movie as a munchkin. Hs said that this is the same Frankie Dee brown that was Ruby Dee's first husband. That was prior to marrying Ossie Davis!! Mr Dee as he was called, resided in Omaha, Nebraska during his final years. He was a midget and was often mistaken for a female by workers in a local Walgreens Drugstore. My dad used to tell me that when employees saw him from behind and heard his high pitched voice it was an easy mistake to make, but Mr Dee was quick to correct anyone who called him such!! My dad made it a habit to speak to Mr Dee every time he came into the store and loudly say "HELLO MR DEE HOW ARE YOU THIS FINE DAY?" He said that this greeting was also a way let people know that Mr Dee was not a little old lady. He told me that Mr Dee used to frequent a local Pharmacy called Lothrop Drugs before it closed and that was where the staff informed him (my dad) about Mr Frankie Dee Brown's marriage to Ruby Dee for 4 years!! So there seems to be a little color in the Munchkins after all!

Author: 3 January 2020
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is one of the most popular children novels of all time.This movie is very sweet.Sets and costume look quite beautifull.The cast does a great job,with Judy Garland as touching Dorothy and Margaret Hamilton as the evil and terrifying Wicked Witch of the West.Truly charming.10/10

Author: 22 May 2014
Review: This quintessential gateway to movie fandom hasn't aged a day in 75 years.
Review_Url: If the ultimate mark of deciding the greatest film of all time is the sheer number of people who have seen it, then a strong case could be made for The Wizard of Oz being the most enduring achievement in Hollywood history. Beloved by everyone from eight to eighty, the musical has entertained countless generations since its spellbinding release in 1939. It remains one of the first cinematic memories entrenched in the minds of many a self-respecting cinephile and now, on the eve of its 75th anniversary, the film has been re-released (in 3D, naturally), in all its visually arresting glory.

Author: 31 July 2007
Review_Url: This is my second-favorite movie of all time. The songs are heartwarming, and maybe the songs we most remember through our lives. It may be so great because it is such an old movie. Now all of the movies are just plain boring and dry. This is a great movie for nearly all ages, but the witch may scare those under 3. When it's on TV, I always try to catch it, but if I miss it, I have the DVD anyway. It doesn't follow the book very closely, but is nevertheless a classic. This movie has a special place in nearly everyone's heart forever. People who don't like it don't know what they're missing. The Wizard of Oz will remain loved for as long as the world turns, not just because it's entertaining, but because it teaches us so much. If you haven't seen it, which is doubtful, go out and rent it now.

Author: 9 September 2006
Review: Talk about iconic - this is Hollywood at its penultimate!
Review_Url: First, acknowledge the importance of WIZARD OF OZ from any point of view, especially in terms of film history, artistic achievement, complete and utter fantasy, cultural icon. The only thing we can hope for is that one day sometime soon someone will aim to achieve a film like this one. While it is true that the oft repeated theme "There's No Place Like Home," is a wishful proclamation both simplistic and conventional, everyone can take pleasure instead in its myriad of sublime details, foremost Judy Garland's performance, indeed, the entire cast's, as well as the unforgettable story, songs, cinematography, sets, costumes, lighting, sound, etc. Hollywood craft at its best.

Author: 25 July 2011
Review: Still a great film after all these long years
Review_Url: When it comes to fantasy films, people of today look at Harry Potter, The Chronicles of Narnia and The Lord of the Rings Trilogy. Most of them are extraordinary in their own way, but The Wizard of Oz still stands out as an all time classic. The Visual Styles, the story and memorable songs still hold up after 72 years. The film was based on the novel and ever since it's release, it has been recognized through out decade after decade, and till this day, people could still confirm this film as a great movie from their childhood. When I watch this film, I get a warm feeling in me that just glows. Even when I was not in the best mood, this film was always their to cheer me up. The visual style is still fantastic, even to this day. It's like a flash of color in your eyes, and that Emerald City still shines like a diamond. The characters are still great. Dorathy is a farm girl who's tired of her life in the farm and dreams of a world full of imagination. Scarecrow is without a brain. Tinman is a human tin without a heart, though is still sentimental and compassionate. The Cowardly Lion is a hilarious Lion who's...well, a coward. And The Wicked Witch is a symbol of childhood fears. Man I remember how much she scared me when I was a child. That black attire, green skin and cackling voice would have kids running for their moms. What else is there to say. The music is done very well and the musical numbers are great. My favorite is when the lion sings about what his life would be if he had the nerve to become king of the forest. Then there's one of the most memorable songs ,sung by Judy Garland, that will live in all our hearts and never be forgotten from time to time.

Author: 1 January 2020

Author: 7 March 2005
Review_Url: From director Victor Fleming (Gone with the Wind), this is one of the most loved musicals in history for all ages, genders and sexualities, and obviously one of my childhood favourites, still is. Basically Dorothy Gale (seventeen year old Judy Garland) from sepia coloured Kansas runs away from home, only to return to the house and get caught in a twister. She lands in a coloured world that appears to be "over the rainbow", Oz, greeted by Gilda the Good Witch of the North (Billie Burke) and the Munchkins of Munchkinland. Then appears The Wicked Witch of the West (Margaret Hamilton) who threatens Dorothy after she killed her sister (the Wicked Witch of the East), and having the ruby slippers put on her feet. To be safe Dorothy starts a journey, following the yellow brick road to the Emerald City to see the Wizard of Oz. Along the way she is joined by the Scarecrow (Ray Bolger) who wants a brain, the Tin Man (Jack Haley) who wants a heart, and the Cowardly Lion (Bert Lahr) who wants courage. They reach the Emerald City and met a scary Wizard, who says he will only grant their requests if they get the broomstick of the Wicked Witch. Of course when Dorothy is captured by the Witch's winged monkeys, Scarecrow, Tin Man and Lion go into the dark castle to save her, and she is eventually killed with a splash of water. The Wizard (Frank Morgan, also playing Professor Marvel, The Gatekeeper, The Carriage Driver and The Doorman) reveals himself as a normal man, but he does and give the three friends a brain (a diploma), courage (a medal) and a heart (a heart shaped ticking clock). After The Wizard floats away in an air balloon, Dorothy says a tearful goodbye before clicking her toes and repeating "There's no place like home" (number 23 on 100 Years, 100 Quotes) returning to sepia Kansas with Auntie Em (Clara Blandick), Uncle Henry (Charley Grapewin), Hunk (Bolger), Zeke (Lahr) and Hickory (Haley). Garland is enchanting, the three boys joining her all get their moments, Hamilton makes a great Wicked Witch, and with magical songs to sing along to, it is a perfect family film. It won the Oscar for Best Music for Herbert Stothart, and it was nominated for Best Art Direction, Best Cinematography, Best Special Effects and Best Picture. Judy Garland was number 82 on The 100 Greatest Movie Stars, she was number 85 on The 100 Greatest Pop Culture Icons, she was number 8 on 100 Years, 100 Stars - Women, and she was number 28 on The World's Greatest Actor, The Wicked Witch of the West was number 4 on 100 Years, 100 Heroes & Villains, the film was number 99 ("I'll get you, my pretty, and your little dog too!") and number 4 ("Toto, I've got a feeling we're not in Kansas anymore.") on 100 Years, 100 Quotes, "Ding Dong the Witch Is Dead" was number 82, and the Oscar winning "Over the Rainbow" was number 1 on 100 Years, 100 Songs, the film was number 3 on 100 Years of Musicals, it was number 23 on The 100 Greatest Scary Moments (for the Witch and flying monkeys), it was number 43 on 100 Years, 100 Thrills, it was number 26 on 100 Years, 100 Cheers, it was number 10 on The 100 Greatest Family Films, it was number 3 on The 100 Greatest Musicals, and it was number 26 on The 100 Greatest Films. Outstanding!

Author: 8 February 2005
Review: Well liked by most people, but under appreciated by the younger generation
Review_Url: Whenever you meet someone who likes this movie, it's most likely someone who loved this as a younger kid and grew up with it. If you ask someone younger than 25, they will probably say they don't like it because it is too juvenile. People who don't like this have no taste for imagination. Just about everyone I know has seen it, and it's very shocking when you meet someone who hasn't seen this movie. Even though this came out almost 70 years ago, it is still a tradition to show this on NBC around Thanksgiving.

Author: 2 July 2007
Review_Url: This is a excellent movie. Judy Garland did very great at Dorthy. Frank Morgon did perfect with these characters and do not forget the Wizard of oz. Ray Bolger did great as the Scarewcrow. Jack Haley did very good at the Tin man. Bert Lahr did Brilliant as the Cowardly Lion. This was based on some books of the Wizard of Oz by the novel of L. Frank Baum. The Singing Midgets as the Munchkins did excellent singing. Billie Burke as Glinda was Beautiful. Toto was very cute. The yellow brick road is beautiful. Buddy Ebsen was a little unshaped to do the Tin Man. This movie is great you will like this all time classic film for the whole family and kids.

Author: 11 March 2019
Review: This flick beats CITIZEN KANE "Heads over Munchkins" for the title of . . .
Review_Url: . . . "Best Movie of All Time." Only very insecure cinema reviewers and "film school" professors (that is, those dudes who think that they--and they alone--are on the verge of "understanding" CITIZEN KANE) could rate the disjointed Orwellian newsreel above "Dorothy Gale's" epic journey to Emerald City. One of these flicks features a Yellow Brick Road; the other, a rotten sled. One film is dominated by the Wicked Witch of the West; the other, by a drunken hag. Aging, alcoholic, gold-digging showgirls are a dime a dozen in Hollywood, but WHO ELSE could curdle your blood by demanding to know "WHO killed my sister?" Or by threatening "I'm going to get you, my pretty, and your little dog, too!" "Charles Foster Kane" may have become "unstuck in time," but his hop-scotching through the years can't hold a candle to "Billy Pilgrim's" anachronistic adventures during SLAUGHTERHOUSE FIVE. (Don't even TRY to picture Mr. Welles caged--in the buff--as he's ogled by alien zoo-goers, along with a similarly unclad Double D Lady!) CITIZEN KANE lacks even ONE chart-topping hit song. (Can you imagine how much better it COULD have been if it had opened to the strains of "Ding dong, old Chuck is dead!"?) Though both KANE and OZ are met to be scathing critiques of American monetary policies as of 120 years ago, when KANE's sledding gets tough, it breaks a snow globe. OZ, on the other hand, keeps its eye on the crystal ball, never losing sight of the fact that the Yellow (Gold) Brick Road is a Dead End Street. Kane pulls most of its punches, devolving into the bathos of maudlin sentimentality. Conversely, OZ promises us that heroes can lead a Popular Uprising against the Established Order, "liquidating" the Fat Cat One Per Centers who think that THEY can Lord it over We True Blue Loyal Patriotic Normal Average 99 Per Center Silent Majority Progressive Union Label Working Stiff Citizens forever!

Author: 1 February 2010
Review: My guess is that this is not what the writer of the book envisioned.
Review_Url: The film has a certain charm about it and considering the time period it was made in it was a very well made film. However, I am betting the writer was not envisioning a musical with people dressed in what looks like Halloween costumes. Once again for the time I am sure they did the best they could, but looking back on it the characters of the Scarecrow, Tin man, and the Lion just are not that impressive, granted they are great for a child to see as that sequel that Disney put out years later had some freaky stuff that spooked me as a kid. That would be more my style now so that is why I am commenting about it, I am not really wanting to disparage this film it is just that my tastes have changed and this is not going to be a movie I can really sit through now. However, I remember it fondly from my childhood so I give it a seven which is a rather good mark to me. The witch was excellent, I do not know who played that part, but she convinced me that she was the bad witch. And while I normally do not care for musicals, the songs in this film were nice and catchy and did not detract from the film as the song sequences in other films tend to do for me. The cast is good, though I do not think Judy Garland should have been Dorthy. She seems to old for the part and at times it seems a bit strange when she is talking as she is talking like a twelve year old and she looks like she could be in her twenties. She has a nice singing voice though so that makes up for it a bit. All in all a good film, I would suggest a remake that had more edge to it, but I figure they would screw it up royally. I do want to try and find that "Return to Oz" movie though as I hear it was rather dark and at times had very frightening imagery.

Author: 23 November 2015
Review: One of the Best Films of all time.
Review_Url: "I could while away the hours, consulting with the flowers, conferring with the rain. My head I'd be a scratching and my thought busy hatching, if I only had a brain". The Wizard of Oz is the Greatest Fantasy and Musical Film of all time. It's a must see for anyone child, and I believe anyone has the right to see this film. One of the most influential films of all time, and the definition of the word classic, The Wizard of Oz will amaze you with its sets, costumes and acting.

The story is concise, funny, dynamic, and very cute until today, it does not need anything. The musical numbers are beautiful as are the simple choreographies that accompany them.

Author: 26 January 2014
Review: Off to the yellow brick road.
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is without a doubt one of the most iconic movies in cinema history, a tale about Dorothy Gale being swept away by a tornado to a magical land, where she is joined by the Cowardly Lion, the Tin Man and the Scarecrow. Together they seek the Wizard to help Dorothy find her way home, going down the famous yellow brick road. Along the way, Dorothy and her friends encounter the famous Good Witch Glinda and the lovable munchkins. They are thwarted by villains, which became some of cinema's most recognizable characters, including the Wicked Witch of the West and the flying monkeys.

Author: 26 September 2021
Review_Url: In 1939 the fantasy film and children's story book came to the silver screens. This had been a huge Hollywood California Production. Filmed as a very productive project and very economical and time consuming. The movie was done in both color and sepia and black and white. There where farm animal's like 🐎 horses, 🐐 goat's, 🐄 cow's, and 🐖 pig's, and a 🐕 dog.

Author: 1 June 2010
Review: A highly charming, heartwarming, imaginative and entertaining film.
Review_Url: Out of all the films I admire and love, "The Wizard of Oz", 1939, is the film I love the most, with all my heart. I grew up with annual showings of the film each year, during the 1970's, as many other people did. This helped make the film such a beloved classic.

Author: 9 August 2019
Review_Url: Probably the first time I have known, from the moment I watched it on VHS as a kid in my grandma's and grandpa's house, a movie will become a big part of me and stay with me through my whole life. Such a simple and warm story about friendship, magic of a child's mind and adventure. Beautifully set and painted scenes, perfect actors and eternally memorable songs along with a story of one of the most legendary authors of children literature make from this movie a lot more than almost 2 hours of movie tape. They make an unforgettable experience which invokes nostalgia, emotions, joy, laughter and they live with you forever. Even now, with 20 years on my shoulders, I can't help myself but to get all teary eyed at the scene where Dorothy is parting with her friends and that will probably be the case for the rest of my life. I can say a lot about this movie, but there are too little words to describe something like that, so just let me recommend it to you with whole of my warm heart! 10/10, a timeless classic!

Author: 1 January 2021
Review: A perfect film on every level
Review_Url: It is a perfect film on every level. You can tell it is lovingly crafted.

Author: 26 September 2009
Review_Url: As incredible as it might seem, phrases like, "Where not in Kansas anymore", and "I'll get you my pretty...and your little dog too!" were completely unknown 70 years ago. "The Wizard Of Oz" set more standards in the industry than just about any other film. If not for this film, "Dorothy", "Toto", and "The Cowardly Lion" would not be house-hold names. If it had never been released, the song, "Over The Rainbow" would never had been heard and it certainly wouldn't be one of the most celebrated songs of all time. Had this film not been released, fantasy as a film genre and even film in general would have turned out very different.

Author: 16 November 2018
Review_Url: Delightful to watch, Fleming and others did a wonderful job in directing this film. It was well developed, and the characters were fun and interactive with each other. I am very much a fan of musicals and think that this is one of the best ones I have seen. The make-up was phenomenal for all the characters, but I did think that the cowardly lion's make-up was a little creepy. Although I do give them props for how well it was considering the time period. Judy Garland was the perfect Dorothy and I loved the character and how they chose to express her.

Author: 13 April 2022
Review_Url: A bit boring for a modern viewer, but charming in its own way. Stupid in the classic old Hollywood way - you know, the way that makes you chuckle a bit condescendingly but also smile at the naiveté with genuine kindness.

Author: 9 May 2018
Review_Url: I grew up watching this movie, so being able to rewatch it and analyze it when was older was amazing. As a child I thought this film was magical, Judy Garland's performance somehow got better and better as I got older and I couldn't picture anyone else as Dorthy besides her. The film is absolutely phenomenal and is still able to capture my heart. The characters and the costume are the perfect combination. Margaret Hamilton as the Wicked With of the West is the best thing to happen to me, her portrayal was so amazing. The voice, and the way she carries herself while she's in character truly captures the 'wickedness' of the character. Overall this film will continue to be one of the best films of all time in my opinion, and I'm never going to be able to think of Kansas as anything else other then Dorthy's home.

Author: 16 January 2023
Review: An Impressive Product of it's time
Review_Url: I didn't expect this film to actually be a musical, but it's songs are solid and the visuals are very vibrant and fun, which makes the cliche and quite bland plot pretty entertaining, the characters are iconic for a reason, even if the acting is a bit dry and cheesy. For the time this a marvel both in terms of quality and the technical hurdles it took to make, even if their were massive consequences needed in order to tackle those hurdles. Overall, its quite fun and enjoyable for a movie of its time, that is iconic for a reason, even if it is at least a decent bit imbalanced with its execution.

Author: 23 August 2005
Review: Social Allegory and Classic Fantasy; a Beautiful and Memorable Story
Review_Url: "The Wizard of Oz" is a powerful and enjoyable allegory of the United States under right-wing Republican government at the beginning of the Twentieth century. But it is also a complex fantasy that works very strongly as an adventure. It is a dream Dorothy Gale has; she is a twelve-year-old girl in Kansas, being raised by her Aunt Em and Uncle Henry, poor chicken farmers. There are three kindly workmen also, but her dog Toto is being sought by mean Miss Alma Gulch, who has been bitten by the little terrier. Unable to get anyone to help, Dorothy runs away just as a tornado is coming. She meets kindly Professor Marvel who gazes into a crystal ball and advises her to go home. She does so but as she arrives, the family is in the cyclone cellar; hit by a shutter, Dorothy is knocked unconscious. When she wakes, she is dreaming, and the house has been carried off by the tornado. Objects whirl by, including Miss Gulch on her bicycle from whose basket Toto escaped earlier; only she turns into a witch on a broomstick. But the house lands safely; and a strange land greets her eyes; female voices sing, garish-hued flowers sprout, and amid ponds there is a yellow brick road and a central plaza. A rainbow-colored bubble approaches; from it steps Glinda, Good Witch of the North. Dorothy finds out her house has killed the Wicked Witch of the Munchkins' land. She has to admit she is no sort of witch; but she becomes the little people's heroine for her deed anyhow. Then out of smoke the Wicked Witch of the West, the other witch's sister, appears and threatens Dorothy. Glinda transfers the dead witch's ruby slippers to Dorothy, warning her to keep them on always. Wanting to get home, Dorothy is advised to follow the yellow brick road to the Emerald City where the Wizard can perhaps help. Along her way, as she goes on with Toto, she picks up three companions--a Scarecrow, a Tin Woodman, and a Cowardly Lion. They all need help too--one lacks a brain, the second a heart, the third courage; so they accompany her, hoping to get help also. The Wicked Witch writes, "Surrender Dorothy" on the sky after trying to steal the slippers when poppy fumes fell the quartet; Glinda wakes them by causing a snowstorm whose chill revives the quartet. In the Emerald City, they gain admittance to the palace. The Wizard, a great talking head, knows why they've come and demands they fulfill a mission first--fetch the Wicked Witch's broomstick from her mountaintop castle. With no choice, the quartet heads for Winkieland and their battle. Flying monkeys kidnap Dorothy and Toto; the others follow to rescue her. The Witch demands the slippers for Toto's life. She tries to remove them from Dorothy's feet and is nearly electrocuted. As an hourglass measures Dorothy's life expectancy in red, Toto escapes. He finds the others, who penetrate the castle and rescue Dorothy. They are recaptured. The Witch starts to execute them, setting fire to the Scarecrow. Dorothy throws a bucket of water on him, splashing the Witch, and she melts to nothing. The people there rejoice that they are free of her. Back at the Palace, Dorothy requests their reward. The Wizard balks. Then Toto pulls aside a drape about a booth, revealing a little man frantically working dials and levers--the Wizard. he admits, "I'm a very nice person, but a very bad wizard." He is able to point out to the three companions that they've already got what they were after; their rescue of Dorothy has proved that. He gives them symbolic gifts. Dorothy wants to go home. He offers to take her there in a balloon--that's how he got to Oz. Leaving the Scarecrow and the others in charge, he takes his balloon up. Toto jumps from the gondola, and Dorothy, running after him, is also left behind. But Glinda arrives and tells her the ruby slippers can help--all she ever had to do was want to go home more than anything. Dorothy follows her instructions and finds herself back at home, lying in bed with her Aunt and Uncle tending her and the farmhands looking on anxiously. She tells them about her dream and says, "There's no place like home!; the film fades out on her radiant face. The Kansas portions of the film, were in sepia tone; Oz was always vivid technicolor.This film as fine special effects and vivid production values. Cinematography by Harold Rosson and the production design by Malcolm Brown contributed to its strength. Noel Langley, Florence Ryerson and Edgar Allan Woolf along with author L. Frank Baum received major credit for the screenplay. The film was directed by Victor Fleming; King Vidor shot the sepia tone sections. Many contributed to the dialogue; Harold Arlen and E.Y. Harburg wrote together or separately most of the songs included. The art direction was by Cedric Gibbons, sets by Edwin B. Wilis, costumes by Adrian. Judy Garland had to play a twelve-year-old girl; camouflage was required. Jack Haley was not the first choice for the Woodman, nor several other principals for their roles. But the cast included Bert Lahr as the Cowardly Lion, Ray Bolger as the Scarecrow, Margaret Hamilton as the Wicked Witch and Miss Gulch, Billie Burke as Glinda, and Frank Morgan as a host of characters including professor Marvel and the Wizard. Charles Grapewin and Clara Blandick were the Uncle and Aunt Em. And the feature was also enhanced by the presence of dozens of little people as Oz's denizens.

Author: 8 December 2017
Review: My favorite musical of all time.
Review_Url: What a classic! THE WIZARD OF OZ brings back so many memories of when my parents first showed me this beautiful movie and it was great to re-watch it again after a few years. A beautiful movie that starts off perfectly in black and white and then transforms to color as we enter the magical land of oz. The colors are so vibrant and the sounds and musically flow beautifully within this musical and are also extremely catchy as well. The comedic characters such as the scarecrow and Tin-man are hilarious as well. Watching such iconic films for the second or third time such as this one are always so much fun because you know you're going to be able to just sit down and watch a great film and can maybe try and catch those details that you maybe missed the last time you watched it. Those details that act as the foundation for these movies such as the intricate lighting and beautiful colors. This film will forever be one of the most iconic musicals of all time.

Author: 4 February 2020
Review_Url: An interesting classic, which ends up being a dream at the end (a twist that I had not remembered. The classic flip from 'B&W' (although it isn't, really), to color is fantastic. A beautiful, cult classic, film, that takes from the book that was already ingrained in US culture. The songs are fun, the character designs all represent a different thing, it's extremely kid friendly. The sets are gorgeous and make for this vast and mythical world. Very entertaining. Note: MGM's response to Disney's hit animation Pinocchio.

Author: 9 May 2018
Review_Url:
I hadn't sat down and watched this movie from beginning to end for several years. After watching it so many times as a kid I think I could replay it in my head with my eyes closed. I call this movie my favorite movie of all time, and I very strongly dislike musicals. But anyway I had the option of watching this film for a cinema history class I am taking and I realized I couldn't remember the last time I sat down and watched it, so I did. 
This movie still has everything. A beautiful soundtrack and score, great acting and singing. It's so well done and nearly everything this movie does still holds up pretty well today. Sure you can tell leaves are plastic, or where the backdrops begin, but the backdrops are beautiful! And the plants are laid out with great detail so as to seem like Dorothy and her friends are really in a poppy field, or a cornfield. This movie is so well rounded with its attention to detail. Every stage of their journey has a unique and identifiable look to it. The costumes are so fabulous and ornate. The Cowardly Lion has always been my favorite character and I love his outfit and his physicality in the role, leaping about on the rocks in the jungle and his wagging tail. It's no wonder this movie has stood the test of time.

Author: 23 January 2020
Review_Url: I like it a lot, I remember watching it a thousand times when I was a little kid.

Author: 23 March 2008
Review_Url: I saw this fabulous film with my beloved Grandmaother and Mother in 1940! I have watched it most of the years since then. I am now age 72. The song, Over the Rainbow always brings a tear to my eyes! Any film that can bring such wonderful memories, is a miracle to those who have seen it. I have helped launch or observed 647 missions into earth orbit, to the Moon, Mars, Jupitier, Venus, and beyond into the stars. The Wizard of Oz got me started. To all Grandparents, I ask that you PLEASE place such a memory into the minds of all your grandchildren to give them a happy memory later in life! Thank you, Holly Wood for this WONDERFUL gift! Clark C. McClelland, former ScO, Space Shuttle Fleet, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, 1958 to 1992.
