Author: 22 March 2009
Review: Ambrose Bierce Will Find the Devil in the Details
Review_Url: While this is my favorite movie of all time primarily because I saw it on TV every year growing up (and could scare my little sister by humming the Witch's Theme any time it was cloudy outside), Ambrose will be seeing it for the first time with adult vision (as he was 97 years old when it premiered), so he will like OZ for reasons different from my initial reactions. L. Frank Baum's original OZ title was the last book Bierce read aloud to his grandchildren, prior to his ill-fated tie-in with Pancho Villa. I presume Baum's fantasy (primarily an anti-gold standard screed) will be fresh in Bierce's mind when he's fully thawed out. The author of THE DEVIL'S DICTIONARY will no doubt agree with me that this is a case where the movie is actually BETTER than the book (along the lines of Peter O'Toole's LORD JIM or William Hurt's recent TUCK EVERLASTING, which barely topped its outstanding youth novel). What he'll notice his first time through OZ (which did not dawn on me until college) is all the dark undertones of Emerald City. Even if unaware of Judy Garland's off-set torture by her foster dad Louie Mayer and his henchmen, Ambrose will be perceptive enough to see how the innocent children's tale is totally sexualized by shoe-horning a young woman with a duct-taped bosom into a role (Dorothy Gale) more appropriate for Shirley Temple. This subliminal perversity is what makes OZ the quintessential American film experience for any age--particularly Bierce's robust 207. He'll also get a special kick out of MGM's crass substitution of in-heat ruby red slippers for Baum's original silver footwear (which no doubt caused L.Frank to turn over in his grave, seeing as how this totally castrated his main purpose for writing OZ in the first place!).

Author: 10 February 2014
Review: Wizard of Oz is a remake?
Review_Url: I was very disappointed to find out that the original Wizard of Oz was filmed in 1925. Thereby revealing this film was not only a remake, but the story line had been altered. Uncle Henry was supposed to be a bad guy. Dorothy was supposed to be a princess, and originally from Oz. After watching the original, it takes away from the 1939 remake. Has anyone ever seen the all black-and-white 1939 version? I remember watching this movie as a teenager. I spent time trying to track down the munchkin that supposedly hung himself on set, and other urban legends. The worst part was the movie being released on DVD, for those that wanted to believe the legends were true. It revealed that not only were these legends false, but brought out other flaws in the film. I would like to see the original film receive at least some credit.

Author: 8 June 2022
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is often considered by many ones of the most famous movies in film history. Based on the children's book "The wonderful wizard of Oz" by L. Frank Baum. It tells the simple story of a young girl named Dorothy( Judy Garland) who when a tornado come through on her family farm in Kansas wake's alone with her dog Toto in the world of Oz a strange and colorful world where she soon finds herself on a journey to meet the Wizard of OZ who can help here get back home. Along the way encounters an assortment of friends from the scarecrow, The Tin man, and The Cowardly Lion. All while dealing with an evil Wicked Witch. A very simple plot yet despite that thing this it still makes for a very appealing family film The cast is a very colorful Buch. Judy Garland for her time was a very beautiful and innocent-looking actress. In many ways, it shows through Dorothy's character as a whole. She's not satisfied with her life at home and dreams of a place of her own choice. In many ways similar to Alice from Alice in Wonderland She witnesses these things, but pretty much accepting of what's going on pretty quick. The rest of the cast like a scarecrow who is so energetic and optimistic they all give good performances. The Wicked Witch what's there to be said about her? Isn't much to describe the original depiction of a Witch the big nose, point hat, and flying broomstick. The cackling it's an iconic character who is just evil for the sake of being evil and that is okay. The music is good though some of the songs can be rather selective. While I've never really cared for the Munchkins. I found them more annoying than lovable and fun. Over the Rainbow and off to see the Wizard are classics. The film also has a legacy for its visuals. Being one of the first feature-length films to use technicolor It does bring a lot of the scenery to life. When you go from the sepia tone to Dorothy opening the door for the first time. It's like when you see Willy Wonka's candy room for the first time. You do feel like you entered a different world. Along with the background Mat-paintings. The Shot of the emerald city alone is a piece of art. Even the costumes for Scarecrow, tin, and Lion are pretty good for 1939. So yeah it simple film by today's standards, but the Whimsicality charm, and artistic tone for the time is still a classic for all ages.

Author: 27 September 2005
Review_Url: Can you remember the first time Dorothy opened the door to Oz and it was in COLOR??? It still makes me excited!! This movie has all the hokey standard Hollywood gimmicks--home is the best place of all, good girl vs evil "witch"--but you still find yourself rooting for Dorothy every time, and waiting patiently for them to get the witch. It never grows old for me!! Even with all the pre-production problems this movie underwent, it is a visually stunning movie (the afore mentioned change to color being the highlight). Judy Garland is perfect as the young naive girl who thinks she can find happiness "over the rainbow", and the rest of the cast is sublime, especially Margaret Hamilton as the Wicked Witch--and yes, she still can give me goose bumps!! Might be a little scary for really young kids, but it's sooooo much fun!!

Author: 5 May 2023
Review_Url: This marvelous fairy tale for children appeals to adults as well. It is a prime example of the three-strip Technicolor process, sold in its entirety to China in the 1970s. Its lessons for kiddies are well illustrated, but it is the spectacular colors are that makes this movie uniquely valuable. They are the same as those used in animation, so the real and fantastic are blended as one. It is also an example of film studio collaboration: several fine directors and writers contributed to its success, not financially realized until it was re-released in 1949. It won Academy Awards for Best Original Score and Song for "Over the Rainbow." This unique show may be viewed with pleasure repeatedly.

Author: 10 July 2005
Review_Url: Anyone who has not seen this film does not know what cinema is. The term, "classic" is far too loosely used but I know of no film more aptly designated. I saw it first when I was 6 years old and I can think of no film that so delighted and enchanted me. Munchkintown was a riot of color that left a lasting impression, Billie Burke, as Glinda, Good Witch of the North, was the incarnation of grace and beauty - and was there ever a more hideous Wicked Witch than Margaret Hamilton? - She scared the Hell out of me and gave me nightmares for days afterwards - talk about a tribute to an actress's performance. It's hard to believe that Ray Bolger as a second choice for the Scarecrow - the Studio originally wanted Jack Haley, who, ironically, became the TinMan! The wonderful Frank Morgan, whose kind nature brought such sweetness to his portrayal of the Wizard was a second choice - the studios wanted W.C. Fields, whose sour nature would, I believe, have left a bitter, aftertaste in the role of Professor Marvel which I believe Frank Morgan fulfilled far more capably. A glorious production.

Author: 30 November 2020
Review: I find it difficult to watch now, but groundbreaking movie that will still be so in 500 yrs
Review_Url:
I watched this first time in around 20yrs after watching it every Christmas for about 20 years and yes it's quite plain to see that we are all in a studio all of the time . Something I don't think I picked up on even in my teens but that's testament of how far the film industry as come from here to now.
Indeed if you could travel in time and show the cast a 60 sec clip of the latest whatever they literally would faint, probably because of the time travelling but you get me.
Yet here it is the first film in colour, I always wonder how the people in the cinemas must have felt when dorothy steps out of the wooden house into the " let's go big on colour" land of the munchkin.

Author: 4 July 2006
Review: Too bad no one sees the whole version anymore
Review_Url: If you watch the TV version, you are truly missing out on one of the most important connections to be made. We all know why the farm hands played the Scarecrow, the Tin Man, and the Cowardly Lion, but do you know why DOrothy sees MIss Gulch as the Wicked Witch of the West? In the version broadcast in the 50's the movie opened with Dorothy walking home from school as the current version hints at. What viewers don't see today is that Toto wondered off into Miss Gulch's garden and was chased out by MIss Gulch with a broom. She threatens to take the dog or at least report Dorothy and Toto to the Sheriff, which she eventually does. DOrothy runs from Miss Gulch toward the farm and when she reaches the entrance road to the farm, the new broadcast version picks up the story. I understand or was led to believe that this portion of the film was edited for TV broadcast and lost in a fire forever. I consider it to be one of the most important parts of the movie.

Author: 6 March 2014
Review: I really hate to give it such a low score but........
Review_Url: .....look it's not so much the movie I dislike I mean I really do like this movie and will continue to like it, but the thing that really make me clinch my fist is the movie's phenomenon. In a way one of the most famous movies of all time has really made the world blind to the true magic that Oz has to offer. How many people do you now who have read the books? Not very many right? The books are just fantastic (most of the time). But for some reason whenever someone tries to adapt closer to the books (AKA 1985 Return to Oz) people are to harsh to it. Leonard Malton and Siskel and Ebert hated that movie because it wasn't the 1939 version. Granted over time people have realized the magic behind the books and Return to Oz (Seriouly I'm like the only one who likes that movie was better the then this one) and I'm sure the years to come people will grow attached as well. So just a recap, I like this movie always have and always will. But at the same time I think it's a little on the overrated side. If you haven't read the book or seen Return to Oz I strongly suggest you do so, it's time to know the truth.

Author: 30 December 2006
Review_Url: I feel sorry for anyone who does not like this movie. They lack the ability to understand what it is all about. They definitely lack the ability to read and write. I have read the negative comments, and none of those individuals could pass sixth grade English. My wife and I own the three disc DVD set, and enjoy them all the time. This movie could not have been better made in any time period. Nothing today can compare with the quality of this 1939 classic. Most of the movies today are just sex or violence, and no story at all. We would far prefer to see this movie 1,000 times than to see a new "junk" movie once. Good luck today to even get close to the quality of The Wizard of OZ.

Author: 19 April 2021
Review: One of the most timeless classics you could ever watch
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is arguably one of everyone's comfort films. Nothing screams your childhood like sitting in front of a static TV watching the movie go from black to white to color. Each of the actor's couldn't have suited there role any better. The score is memorable, the sets of the film are full of life, and overall the movie has very much like a fairytale or storybook feel to it. The lighting and color seemed a bit washed out and overdone at times; I think it's because the film was never advertised to be in color so they wanted their audiences to experience the wow-factor of a lifetime. Despite any dull moments or scenes that today would make you cringe or skip past it, overall this is a movie that will always age in a positive manner for years to come. It never gets old, nor does the comfort it provides fade away.

Author: 21 September 2021
Review_Url: Anyone who reviews this at less than a 10/10 basically has no place reviewing films because they know nothing about the history of this art form. End of my review.

Author: 19 January 2005
Review: A magical film that will capture your imagination!
Review_Url: Since the story of The Wizard of Oz has fallen into the realm of common knowledge and pop culture, I won't get into it here. If you don't know the story, you absolutely must see this film. Don't even read the rest of the review, just go see it! This movie "captured my imagination" when I was a kid, and to see it now, after over twenty years was to rediscover it. Honestly, it was like seeing an old friend. However, I got even more out of seeing it now than I did as a child. Aside from the awe-inspiring land of Oz, the brilliant use of Technicolor to suggest another "world," and the tender performance of Judy Garland, this film contains little bits of Wiz-dom that make it that much more enjoyable years later. Warm performances from Frank Morgan, as Professor Marvel/The Wizard of Oz (among other roles in the picture), Ray Bolger, as Hunk/The Scarecrow, Bert Lahr, as Zeke/The Cowardly Lion, and Jack Haley, as Hickory/The Tin Man, all add to the sincerity of the film. Margaret Hamilton is great as the heartless Ms. Gulch and the sinister Wicked Witch of the West. I would recommend this movie to anyone, especially anyone with children. This is a wonderful fantasy/musical! Truly delightful!

Review_Url: THIS IS PROBABLY MOST INTERESTING MOVIE SINCE SLICED BREAD. DOROTHY SEEMS TO LIKE HER DOG BETTER THAN ELMIRA. ELMIRES SAYS THE DOG BIT HER SO SHE WANTS HIM DESTROYED. A TORNADO PICKS UP DOROTHY'S HOUSE AND THROWS IT, AND SHE IS KNOCKED UNCONSCIOUS, AND WAKES UP IN OZ (YET STILL SLEEPING). SHE MEETS THE TIN MAN, THE SCARE CROW, AND THE LION. SHE MAKES FRIEND WITH THEM , AND SHE WANTS TO FIGURE OUT HOW TO GET HOME. SHE EVENTUALLY DEFEATS THE WICKED WITCH OF THE WEST WITH WATER. DOROTHY AND HER FRIENDS GET AWARDED BY THE WIZARD OF OZ AND SHE EVENTUALLY AWAKES IN HER BED WITH HER FAMILY WATCHING OVER HER.

Author: 25 April 2019
Review_Url: This movie is the reason why I fell in love with musical! Aside from the cast being completely nuts, it is wonderful to see that when you are a professional in the industry, your work is remarkable and truly insightful to witness. Judy Garland was a gem in the business and it was so unfortunate for the world to have lost such a wonderful talent. The bright side of this is that we still have all of her work and this is one of the greatest pieces she has in her trophy shelf! You could never get tired of watching this film and singing along with these memorable songs cause we're off to see the wizard, the wonderful wizard of Oz!

Review_Url: When I read the book by L.Frank Baum I became a fan of it the and wanted to see this movie because I was astonished with the mystical land of Oz.The wizard of Oz is about a girl called Dorethy who gets trapped in her house during a storm and ends up in a strange land with her dog called Toto.There,she has to follow a yellow brick road that leads to an emerald city so she can meet the wizard of Oz.On her journey, she meets a scarecrow that wants a brain,a tin man that wants a heart and a cowardly lion that wants courage.A few annoying songs can drive you insane but there is no real hassle because there is a good plot and the acting is decent enough.The only bad thing is it doesn't show how hard they traveled to the emerald city like it dose in the book and the length it took for Dorethy to get to the good witch of the north.The wicked witch of the west,I have to say has a very sensitive hate of water because a small splash killed her.

Author: 26 April 2009
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz (1939) is a fantasy musical film from MGM during its golden years. The actors that play the Oz roles are Ray Bolger (Scarecrow), Jack Haley (Tin Man), Bert Lahr (Cowardly Lion), Margaret Hamilton (Wicked Witch of the west), Frank Morgan (Emerald City Doorman/Cabbie/The Wizard's Guard/The Wizard of Oz), and Judy Garland (Dorothy Gale). Also all these actors and actresses (except Dorothy Gale) play a double role in Kansas and Oz. The Kansas roles are Ray Bolger (Hunk), Jack Haley (Hickory), Bert Lahr (Zeke), Margaret Hamilton (Miss Almira Gulch), and Frank Morgan (Professor Marvel). During the opening of the movie there is a message saying, "For nearly forty years this story has given faithful service to the Young in Heart; and Time has been powerless to put it kindly philosophy out of fashion. To those of you who have been faithful to it in return...and to the Young in Heart...we dedicate this picture." This makes the movie sounds like it's a fantasy for children or more or less for little girls. As the film progresses Dorothy comes in the farm to complain about Almira and how she is being mean to Toto the dog. Later Almira comes to take her dog with a sheriff warrant. As she rides the bike back to town with the dog in the back in the basket, the dog escapes and runs back to Dorothy. As soon as the dog comes back Dorothy realizes that Almira is going to come back and she decides to run away. As she is traveling she runs into professor Marvel, whom she asks if she can travel with him. But later the professor decides that he doesn't want her to come with him some he makes up lies about Dorothy aunt getting sick. As Dorothy rushes back to her aunt's farm there is a tornado by the farm. Locking the animals away the farm residents decide to go underground. When Dorothy arrives the tornado is close to the farm and the trees are flying off the ground as Dorothy runs to the house. This scene doesn't make sense because on average a tree weights more than a human being. Dorothy hides in the house and the window hits her; resulting she gets knocked unconscious on the bed. When she wakes up she realizes she is inside the tornado and she sees Almira riding her bike laughing and Almira turns into the wicked witch. While the tornado stops she realizes she is in some fantasy land (Oz). Dorothy is accused of being the savior of the munchkin people because she fell with her house on the wicked witch of the East that controlled them (munchkin people). The mayor of the munchkins calls it the day of independence because the death of the witch. Later Dorothy goes on a journey wearing the ruby slippers that the wicked witch of the west wants. While on her journey to meet the wizard that can take back to Kansas she meets a scarecrow (that is not scary), a tin man (who needs oil), and a tiger (who is a coward). While they are on the journey the wicked witch of the west plots a plan to put the crew to sleep. It works but only the scarecrow and tin man are not placed under the spell. They start yelling help and the good witch of the north makes it snow and wakes them up. They reach the city and all the residents are wearing green as they freshen up the wicked witch of the west come and scare the residents by spelling surrender Dorothy, leaving everyone in panic. Dorothy realizes that there is no wizard of oz and she breaks down and starts crying; as she is telling her story about her aunt getting sick the emerald city door man hears her and takes her to the wizard. When they see him they are petrified of the great fire and the floating head of the wizard. The wizard decides to grant them their wish only if they bring the broomstick of the witch of the west. Dorothy and the three go and search for the witch in the haunted forest and Dorothy and her dog get kidnapped by flying monkeys. Toto escapes to look for the other three and takes them to rescue Dorothy. Dorothy kills the witch with water, which is one of the worst endings one can think of. The crew gets the broom back and goes back to the wizard of oz and Dorothy discovers that he is a fake. Wizard leaves Dorothy and the good witch of the north arrives and tells her the truth that she can go back whenever she pleases. Then Dorothy awakens with her aunt and friends there and she tells them her story of fantasy. This picture is a little bit childish but it can be easily the movie of the 1940's, because of the color tone added to the black and white picture as soon as Dorothy goes into her fantasy state. The cuts and scenes of this movie are in a proper sequence except for the fact when she is in the tornado and the house falls there needs to be more details. When the house falls the scene doesn't show the witch getting hit and the impact of the house falling. The wizard of Oz is a movie that is remembered and cherish by many younger generations. The lesson learned from this movie is that running away is never good.

Author: 19 April 2021
Review_Url: I think the Wizard of Oz is one of the movies everyone has seen at one point of their life. It starts out as black and white confusing the crowd but once she enters her dream in the oz, color appears on tv for the first time in cinema history. Dorothy is played by Judy Garland she is a young girl on a farm in Kansas surrounded by her family. Until a tornado comes and knocks her in to a deep dream that know one ever imagined before. She wakes up to a fantasy world surrounded by good witches and bad witches. These witches are people she know's in real life but her imagination takes control of the whole world. She is along side her uncles played as the lion, the scarecrow and the tin man. Of course you know what path she takes to get out of the fantasy world, the famous yellow brick rode. She has to get to the wizard of Oz but comes across conflict between the wicked witch of the west. How will she overcome this obstacle, i guess theirs only one way to find out. I highly recommend showing this movie to a group of young kids.

Author: 3 August 1999
Review_Url: A beautiful masterpiece starring the magnificent Judy Garland as young Dorothy Gale is what "The Wizard of Oz" is, and when I saw this movie as a child, I watched it over and over again, and became a big Judy Garland fan. Judy has a sweet, powerful, golden voice which can echo in the dark and become so unforgettable, and Judy was so ahead of her time during her career.  I think it's wonderful that her daughter, Liza Minnelli, who I also adore, carries on her mother's legacy.  Liza, too, has an unforgettable voice as well, very brassy, cool, and sexy -- this woman can sing -- her voice is like a kiss!  Like mother like daughter!

Author: 15 September 1999
Review: Succeeds becuase it's got a timeless lesson that we can all relate to
Review_Url: Every person in America (and most people all over the world) that is over the age of 5, but usually younger, has seen The Wizard of Oz.  Just about all of them have undoubtedly seen it more than once, either on video or on its yearly TV broadcast.  Why is it so popular and such a part of our culture?  My guess would be that it hasn't gotten old one bit, even though it was made 60(!) years ago, and there is a reason for that.  No matter how old you are, no matter what generation you're part of, you can relate to Dorothy (wonderfully played by Judy Garland) as she yearns to break free and find something somewhere else, but when she finds that something, discovers it's not so great because it doesn't have the familiar comforts of home. Home is what matters, or to quote it for the umpteenth time, there's no place like home.  Everyone feels that way, so we can all relate to her because we all know what it feels like.  Yes, it's got marvelous splashes of color, gorgeous scenery and costumes, great acting and wonderful, classic musical numbers, and that's also a large part of its appeal.  But, whether we want to admit it or not, when you narrow it down, the main reason it was seen by so many people in theaters, by even more people on TV, and now by thousands of kids on video, (And some adults, too.  Admit it!) is because it's timeless and has a lesson that is not dated and has never lost its value.  Say you love it cause Judy's got pretty shoes, or because you've watched it every year and it's just a tradition, but when you look deeper, that's the real reason.

Author: 23 July 2017
Review_Url: So many years has passed and i still love this! completely timeless and a beautiful story, Ms. Garland was perfect and even on that time every character was created to perfection, not CGI or many special effects and is just a perfect story for a Sunday night and a movie night with my friends, every layer from the characters is beautifully created and thanks to Hollywood that hasn't had the need to remake this beautiful master piece.

Author: 18 November 2003
Review_Url: I don't care how jaded you are about the moviegoing experience; this simple fairy tale is a must-see for kids from six to a hundred and six.  Unmatched visuals, a great archetypal story and solid ensemble acting make this movie peculiarly invulnerable to criticism.  If you can, see it in a big theatre (revival houses seem to run it during the holidays around Thanksgiving to X-mas) because the technicolor is truly amazing on the full size screen.  A DVD copy on a big tv will also yield things you may not have seen before, like the wacky flowers growing out of the munchkins' shoes, which I'd never previously noticed.   It's sixty four years old but still wonderful, especially for children.  10 / 10.

Author: 12 March 2008
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is considered one of the greatest movies of all times and will forever be remembered. The best part of the movie in my mind is that there are several different characters with their own very different personalities. Another great part of the movie is how advanced the special effects were. The scene where Dorothy gets caught in the twister and she sees things fly by her window seems pretty advanced for 1939. This movie is great because of how it appeals not just to children, but adults too. One of greatest things about the film is how the mise en scene is incorporated into it by director Victor Fleming. Mise en scene is a wide array of elements seen on camera. These different elements in the Wizard of Oz include the set and how it is arranged, the characters and their different dynamics and the props used by those characters. As I have stated in my title I think this movie is amazing and it has had one of the greatest impacts on films we see today. In the film The Wizard of Oz directed by Victor Fleming, Fleming understands the importance of mise en scene and utilizes his set, characters, and props to lift the mise en scene to a different dimension which, in turn, has enabled his film to become one of the true classics and most renowned movies of all time.

Author: 6 April 2019
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is an awesome film. I always thought it was cool how it starts in black and white and switches to color when Dorothy arrives "over the rainbow". The twister scene when the mean old lady becomes the Wicked Witch always freaked me out. Judy Garland does a fantastic job as well as her three companions but, Margaret Hamilton's performance as the Wicked Witch of the West is second to none. I believe she was even burnt a few times. Without Hamilton's brilliant portrayal of such an evil character, the movie is just not the same. The munchkins are nice and Dorothy's ruby red slippers are sparkling but, when the witch comes around everyone runs and hides. Until they realize that all they needed was a bucket of water lol. But, even that scene when the witch is "melting, melting" is done just right and fits right in with the movie. I love this film and I think people will be loving it for a long time to come.

Author: 27 December 1999
Review_Url: I remember watching OZ on television at my great-grandmother's home in the very early 60s--maybe 62 or 63 (I was only 5 years old).  Grandma had the only color TV in our family, so my Mom and Dad brought us kids to her house to watch it.  Grandma (who was 43 when OZ premiered in '39) loved the film and wanted to share it with all her "children."  Anyway, I've just bought my third VHS copy of the film--the most recent release.  I'm so thrilled with how clear and clean the picture is--the sound, despite being touted as being "digitally remastered. . .in true stereo, is okay, but not as good as the picture.  It's a true classic--and as I type this I realize that I am the same age now as my great-grandmother was when OZ was first released.  Our grand-parents always know what's best for us, don't they?  THE WIZARD OF OZ rules!!!

Author: 2 October 2012
Review_Url: You follow your own yellow brick road and choose what way you want to go. The writer did an amazing job with putting parallels into the story. I like how in the beginning of the movie there was a short story about Dorothy and her life and after she was bumped her head and went to Oz, the same story was told but in much more detail. If I were to write a story with parallels this movie would be a great example to look at. Part of the parallel writing included having the main characters show up in Kansas and Oz and the non main characters only showing up in Kansas or Oz. The workers on Dorothy's aunt and uncles' farm in Kansas were also in Oz. The worker that told Dorothy to have a brain was the scarecrow, the worker who told Dorothy to have a heart was the tin man, and the worker who told Dorothy to have courage was the lion. Mrs. Gulch from Kansas was one of the wicked witches and the professor Dorothy met when she was trying to run away was the wizard. The non main characters were mainly in Oz, for example, the munchkins, flying monkeys, and the soldiers the wicked witch had.

Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is a wonderful film. Watching it on the big screen is truly adds a lot to the film -expecially in Kansas. I watched fellow Kansans smile, cry, and laugh. Dorothy Gale is a Kansas farm girl and pretty tough. I wonder about the Cowardly Lion. He seems a little funny. The monkeys are scary. Yet it all comes back to Kansas. I think about times I've traveled and the flight attendant will say "click your heels three times, you're back in Kansas." Every time it makes me smile. To know that Kansas is known for something that is so special to so many people is very gratifying. Gee, it makes me feel sorry for states like New Jersey that lack the sort of identity that Kansas has. Clerks and Jersey Girl are fine yet Oz is clearly in a whole other category. Truly a classic and one of my favourites.

Author: 31 July 2018
Review: Entertaining, but Baum's great story lost in big screen transition
Review_Url:
There is no question that from a Hollywood screenplay and production perspective, the "Wizard of Oz" is high on the list of achievements for excellence. The movie, in terms of cast, score, production is exciting, entertaining and thrilling. The movie is sure to get glowing reviews for decades to come. However, there is a difference between a review which states the obvious about cast and production, and one which goes a bit further. Despite its grandness, my overall complaint about the movie is a problem not specific to this film itself, it is the industry problem of not staying true to the book for any number of reasons, particularly sensitive issues. Sadly, the more movies one reviews which have their beginnings in literature, the more visible the altering of story lines becomes visible and troubling, as do the motives for such alteration. The Hollywood credo seems to be that Issues of politics, social condition, religion and race must be handled "delicately."
 
After decades of study, what we now know about "The Wizard of Oz" is that it is not a simple fairy tale for children. That the book was banned in libraries across the country, and religious leader called on movie house to ban screenings, should give you enough pause. The story itself is a social and political commentary on America and the rise of populism, the challenge to the US monetary gold system, the struggle of farmers and factory workers and so on. Don't fell bad if you missed this. It took about 30 years for scholars to figure this one out.

Author: 12 June 2005
Review_Url: This is the classic children's film. I starred as the Cowardly Lion in a nearby theatre production and it was very, very inspirational. There have been so many different translations and opinions of this film, but honestly, it is one of the greatest films of all time. From the start, you are immediately "sucked" into the storyline, relating to Dorothy in those times in which you were neglected by people. THen as you are transported into this technicolor world, surrounded by short people and talking objects and creatures, you imagine a world that is perfect (except for the wicked witch of course) After seeing the movie, you are captivated by the imaginative world that has been created inside your mind. That is what a good movie is about, it's about being more than just a kid, but the most important person to a group of people. This makes up for the neglected childhood. :D

Author: 7 July 2002
Review: Fun for everyone, still looks extravagant and beautiful.
Review_Url: It's hard to judge a film like this, having grown up with it.  I can't tell where sentiment ends and my critical eye begins.  Suffice it to say that it is a wonderful rendition of Baum's story, with clever and amusing songs, and people of all ages can watch it.  There are the occasional scary scenes of intense suspense and music that may frighten someone under three, but even these pass and are only part of what the screen presents you.  The casting is perfect, the set design still amazes me.  Dedicated and simple renditions of great ideas will trump the highest technological achievements if that technology serves a flat story or a poor imagination.  The Wizard of Oz certainly qualifies as one of the more imaginative movies of all time, and the skill the players and the technical aspects only further its quality. In short, one of the finest films ever made.

Author: 26 October 2021
Review: Mary Lou moved into my house in 1973 and I can never get over how she looked like Judy Garland..
Review_Url: Mary Lou Godbe told me her family had lived near, or in, Hollywood before moving to Salt Lake City. She said they did and that her Great Grandfather was William Samuel Godbe. I I wondered because I drove a California Yellow Cab and one day I noticed 2 rainbows in the sky. I've never thought of chasing a rainbow before or since then but that day a Pot of God with the end of the rainbow in it appeared on my front seat.

Author: 1 May 2023
Review_Url: When the movie opens, MGM's logo is colored sepia, like any other black and white movie. Dorothy's life in Kansas is limiting, spending her whole childhood listening to her parents. In her most intimate moment she sings "Over the Rainbow", a slow track that was almost cut out of the film, and later went on to win Best Original Song at the Academy Awards. It took me many watches throughout my life to realize the characters of the Scarecrow, Tin Man and Cowardly Lion appear in the first portion of the movie as some farmers. When Dorothy first escapes, she meets odd Professor Marvel who is played by Frank Morgan; Morgan later plays many characters in the land of Oz, including the Wizard himself. I do remember Miss Gulch, the bitter old woman attempting to have Dorothy's dog taken away from her, being the Wicked Witch of the West. This is made explicitly clear when Dorothy's house is swirling through the tornado and the old lady is seen flying in her bike, which turns into a broom as she is dressed in a stereotypical witch outfit. So it's a small cast, really. At least until the Munchkins appear, after Dorothy opens the door of her house to Munchkinland.

Author: 3 July 2005
Review_Url: Would somebody please verify something for me before I begin to doubt my own sanity? When we gathered around the T.V. set in the early sixties, to watch the WiZard of Oz, (it came on once a year, on Sunday, from 6:00 to 10:00. This is four hours! The commercial breaks then were 1 minute, so we actually got about 3 and a half hours of show. How does this translate into 112 minutes in 2005? I also went to the movies in 1976 to see the uncut version, which ran over 3 hours. What happened to the rest of the movie, and why isn't it mentioned?

Author: 3 March 2012
Review_Url: Yes Wizard of Oz is a classic ,however it is only a classic if you have never read the books, and yes Judy Garland made an okay Dorothy except she was the wrong age,the problem with this movie is that if you have never read the books one would think that the story ends after Dorothy's friends get their "gifts" so to speak and she taps her heels three times . Except it doesn't because Oz was not a fantasy dream world Dorothy dreamed up .The movie leaves out a whole lot and gives it the cookie cutter Hollywood ending . So if you want a good version of Wizard of Oz watch one of the cartoons most particularly one of the anime versions since they seem to go by the book. The other thing that is wrong with this movie is how Dorothy's character was butchered in the book Dorothy is this spunky resourceful little girl who doesn't need rescuing but Judy Garland plays her like this helpless damsel in distress and that's not who Dorothy is . The girl who played her in " Return to Oz" did a much better job

Author: 9 September 2003
Review_Url: Who wouldn't want to visit a world composed of everything and everyone beautiful or mysterious, where you are the centerpoint of all action, princess, heroine, friend? Oz is such a world and the incomparable Judy Garland is the fortunate visitor, with majestic results. Certainly one of the finest films ever made, "Wizard" is a happy accident resulting from perfect casting and the studio system that faithfully churned out it's product through superior organization despite upper echelon headaches. Garland could not have been improved on, the sets, music and pacing are perfection. Judy sums up the hopes of all mankind in her unmatched rendition of "Over the Rainbow", IMO the finest song in film. If you haven't seen it, I envy you. Enjoy!

Author: 10 April 2019
Review: Still hits the mark on so many levels
Review_Url: I still remember watching the Wizard of Oz for the first time with my Grandma and being absolutely terrified of the wicked witch, and even more terrified of the flying monkeys. Watching the film today, it's safe to say that these things are just as terrifying as they were 15 years ago. But more importantly, in terms of entertainment, the movie definitely still holds up. It's one of those rare films that can be enjoyed by kids and adults alike. The costumes, set designs, and vivid on-screen colors are a piece of art on their own. Add the elements of musical numbers, action-filled scenes, and many unique, dynamic characters, and you have something pretty remarkable. The fact that it was made in 1941 astounds me. Recently, I have been watching many movies from this time period, but this one always stands out above the others One scene that backs this up comes towards the beginning of the movie, as Dorothy leaves the sepia-toned world she knows and enters the dynamic, colorful world of Oz. I recently learned that no color editing was done throughout this scene. Rather, they painted her house sepia-colored and even painted a double this way. Then, as she exits through the doorway of her house, the double steps out of the shot, and Judy Garland steps in, wearing her baby blue dress and sparkling red slippers. So much thought went into those few seconds of the scene, but, because it was so well thought-out, it became something masterful. I think a lot of people would say that this specific scene is etched into their memory. Even if you can't enjoy the story, it is easy to appreciate the production for what it is.

Author: 8 December 1998
Review_Url: I have been watching "The Wizard of Oz" since I was little and it just keeps getting better all the time.  The film itself is a classic in it's own right.  The sets and costumes are wonderful as is the cast.  Margaret Hamilton really shines as the wicked witch.  Her performance is sill my favorite in the film.  Judy Garland is perfect as Dorothy.  This film has withstood the test of time over and over again and it will continue to do so in the years to come.  This is not just a movie for kids but instead it is a movie for people of all ages.  Highly recommended!  Don't miss it!  A true classic!

Author: 28 October 2002
Review_Url: This marvellous film is so much a part of my childhood that I can't really look at it too objectively.  But the more I watch it as an adult, the more impressed I am by the sheer quality of the sets, the special effects and the make-up.  As a child you take it for granted, but to think all this was done in 1939.  For serious Oz fans I would highly recommend Aljean Harmetz's fascinating book, which contains all the background info about the shoot and the planning of the film.  The DVD is also good value and contains several scenes which were taken out of the finished version (such as the well-known "Jitterbug" sequence.)

Author: 6 July 2003
Review: Why Isn't This In The Top Five?
Review_Url: I've just watched "The Wizard of Oz" for what has to be the 400th time. Of course I watched it every year as a kid when it came on TV (usually in the spring, usually on CBS), and of course it was always a family favorite. But now when I watch it, I try to view it through my "film buff glasses," trying to see how it compares with other films of its day.  I'm attempting to put sentimentality aside and view it critically from all angles.  Sorry to say, either I'm a "failure" as a film buff, or this is certainly one of the top five movies ever made.

Author: 13 September 2005
Review_Url: This is the best movie ever made. I remember as a child seeing this movie 3 to 4 times a year (pre-cable). You can not compare it to movies made today, or any movie since. Just consider that it was made in 1939, and in color, when black and white was the standard for most all films until the mid 60's. This film set the bar too high to be touched. It was the largest production of it's and any other time. I recommend the DVD version of this film, as the history of the filming is as enticing as the movie itself with a deep history and fun facts. Sure to delight people of all ages, this movie is timeless. Class grade A golden era movie!

Review_Url: This film is a great musical; I love the songs, the acting, the characters, and the cinematography. The songs are such classics and I don't think there's a lot of people that haven't heard of the songs or listened to them. The acting and characters are great; I think the actors did a great job in portraying the characters the developing the relationship with other characters. I absolutely love how the film went from no color in Kansas to having color in the Land of Oz; I thought that was very clever. Judy Garland was fantastic as Dorothy; I think she portrayed her perfectly and her singing voice was amazing. I gave this 8 stars because it's another great classic and I would definitely recommend this film to anyone.

I think she would relate and like the 2nd one a lot better than this. Honestly if it was not for the musicals this movie would get an 8 or 9 easily! Author: 5 January 2000
Review_Url: What a pleasure it was to finally see The Wizard of Oz for the first time on the big screen when it was re-released in 1998. This was one of the first films I watched as a child and it became a annual ritual to watch it while I was growing up. Nevertheless, I was surprised by how well I responded to it when I watched it on the big screen some 15 years or so after I thought I had outgrown it. The energy and wonder of the film still hold up and I was reminded of so many movies I have seen in the last twenty years that borrowed things from this movie. The performances by Judy Garland and Margaret Hamilton are still my all time favorite female lead and supporting performances. I've seen this movie maybe 15 times by now but I'll probably see it again before long.

Author: 3 December 2001
Review: This movie always has a place in my heart!
Review_Url: I was so little when I first saw this movie that I cannot remember the exact details but I do remember how it used to air on television around Thanksgiving time and my family used to gather around as though it was a big event.  Then we recorded it and the tape fell apart literally since I watched it so many times.  I have it on DVD now and I love watching it.  I let my eight year old nephew (six at the time) watch it with me for his first time when I bought the DVD.  What a delight to watch the expressions on his face when he first saw the witch, the munchkins and even more so.. The Cowardly Lion, Scarecrow and Tin Man.  This will always be a classic and I can't wait to pass it on further down the family.  It is so nice to see a down to earth film, yet how much was put into it.  The film may have been made back in 1939 but it will always be a timeless classic!

Author: 13 February 2006
Review_Url: I first saw this movie when I was a little kid. Since then, it's been one of my favorite all time films. Dorothy Gale (Judy Garland) is a farm girl with a little puppy and a great singing voice. At first, the movie starts off in black and white--then it springs into something almost unseen in 1939--color. I love the horse of many colors! I love the Wizard! I love everything about this movie. Along with the songs (Somewhere over the Rainbow was voted the best song of the 21st century), the lovable cast, and the sinister witch--all the movie needs is a batch of popcorn. I've seen this movie many times and the magic is still there when I watch it again. If you haven't seen this movie, I suggest you do. It's one of my favorites--and it could be yours too. I'm almost 20, and the magic has never left for me. By the end of the movie, you too will be saying "There's no place like home." This movie is fun for people of all ages. Believe me. Better yet, see it.

Author: 3 May 2018
Review_Url: Premiered in 1939, The Wizard of Oz was ahead of it's time for a number of reasons. It was one of the first films made with technicolor AND in black in white giving it both a past and futuristic feel. Although not talked about often it also had no main male hero, the Scarecrow, the Lion and the Tin man were all considered to be "common man" roles whereas the main character is Dorothy and the only real powered figures in the film were the White Witch and the Wicked Witch of the West. No movie prior to this had made the most powerful and most revered character a woman

Author: 17 May 2000
Review_Url: Everyone must watch this movie when he or she is young. This will be a part of your childhood memories. That wonderful fantasy that we all want to realize: to go over the rainbow. To escape a daily existence to be in a world of munchkins,, witches good or bad, cowardly lions, talking scarecrows, tin woodmen; we all want that. The added benefit is that this movie is so well done - forget that it hardly matches the actual story by L. Frank Baum - it gets better with every advance in technology. My DVD is fabulous in terms of colour and remastered quality - a jarring note it is damn user-unfriendly! The menu is impossible to navigate. Go and see it again - at least once on the big screen.

Author: 29 March 1999
Review: On 16mm at my sister's birthday party in 1963
Review_Url: My introduction to this truly great film was in 1963 aged 4,  when my father hired the 16mm print to show on his 16mm projector at my sisters' 8th birthday party. A girl at the party, Caroline Theobald, screamed in terror so violently when the wicked witch appeared that my father had to stop the projector and the parents had to be called! My older brother and my 2 sisters only saw the entire film the next day! I have now seen the film about 30 times and for me it is the greatest of all family films!

Author: 21 April 2019
Review: Great Cinematography and Use of Color in Visual Storytelling.
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is an account of identity incorporation and transitioning. In the film, Dorothy isn't at all fitting into life around her, which is the reason why Kansas is portrayed in black and white. Following the tornado she ends up in a peculiar land, this new land is in color since it is a position of tangibility, where her issues can be carried on an excellent scale and be managed. The story attempts to tell the message that our lives are sure to contain frightening and challenging experiences, but by making companions with the best parts of yourself and refusing to give the obstacles a chance to shield you from seeing what's great in life and what's great in other individuals, there will dependably be encouraging points throughout everyday life.

Dorothy Gale appeals to everyone, and she shows us how if we just have a brain, a heart, and the courage to do what's right, then we'll always find our way home.

Author: 10 May 2005
Review: A childhood classic that is still magic
Review_Url: When I was growing up in the 70s, The Wizard of Oz was re-released theatrically. My mother made sure that I went to see it, even though I can't have been over 4 years old. I remember the thrill when Dorothy opened the door of her black and white house, to see the glorious colour of Oz. Each year the thrill would be repeated, as The Wizard of Oz was compulsory viewing in our house when it came on TV during the holidays. I even had Dorothy doll, complete with basket and Toto (I wonder what happened to that...).

Author: 4 August 2001
Review: She had to learn it for herself
Review_Url: A couple of people have said they've wondered why Glinda would think that Dorothy would not have "believed" her that all she had to do to get back home was click her heels.  I've wondered about that too, and have come up with this suggestion:  Perhaps Glinda was *not* referring to clicking the shoes when she said Dorothy "wouldn't have believed me."  Perhaps she was referring to what Dorothy needed to learn from her adventures in Oz.

Author: 13 December 2019
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is a classic when it comes to musicals. Mostly everyone has seen or knows about this movie. The story is fantastic with an excellent plot and the message behind the movie is great. The acting and the soundtrack was excellent to watch. One of my favorite parts is when the film turns from a B&W film to a color film.

Author: 15 April 2019
Review_Url: This movie is awesome. I have watched it many times and every time I watch it I learn something new. You jus have to see it yourself.

Author: 6 July 2003
Review_Url: What can you say about a film that to this day is played yearly without skipping a beat? In a word: Unforgettable. I'm not much for musicals but this film truly is a work of art that can be enjoyed by both children and adults alike. The cinematography, especially for its time is downright remarkable. Judy Garland is forever immortalized and rightly so as her portrayal of Dorothy Gale cannot be imagined with no one but her(Shirley Temple??? c'mon!!!no way!!!). To do a remake of this film would be blasphemy for nothing can be added or deleted. The supporting cast of Ray Bolger, Bert Lahr, and Jack Haley are remarkable as well. When they say" they don't make them like they used to",this film is a fine example. Judy was so adorable. I get a soft spot when I think about her. A true classic.

Author: 16 November 2004
Review_Url: Adapted from Frank Baum's children book "The Wizard of Oz", the movie by Victor Fleming depicts wonderful art of stroy telling.

Author: 31 October 2005
Review: Dorothy twirls from Kansas to a lesser place (if that's possible)
Review_Url: Don't expect full frontal nudity - but otherwise you'll be completely satisfied! A terrific musical comedy about the benefits of being satisfied with what you've got. Dorothy sets out to meet the much-rumored-about wizard of Oz to get her back to Kansas, singing, dancing and frolicking all along. You simply have to be swept away by the witty songs, the splendid choreography and the charming dialogue. Even if you don't like kids in movies (like I do) you will be charmed by Judy Garland and the incredibly well-cast inventory of this film (munchkins, scarecrow, tinman and all....) Just realize how influential this film has proved to be (Toto, the dog, inspired the name of a rockband; the yellow brick road supplied us with a very good Elton John - tune...) Who would've thought that there is no better place than home? It isn't! If you should not believe it - watch "The Wizard of Oz"!!!!

Author: 10 April 2019
Review_Url: I usually dont like musicals. I remember watching The Wizard of Oz as a child and seeing it now, gives me a whole different perspective on it. The movie was made really well and the color was very advanced for it's time. the significance of this movie is how people want things they already have, but dont even know it. in example, the lion wanted courage, but he helped fight the wicked witch. they all wanted things that they already had. overall, I really liked the movie and it's a classic that everyone should watch.

Author: 10 April 2019
Review: My shoddy explanation of the meaning of this movie
Review_Url: Throughout the movie, there are two "in your face" meanings of the story as a whole. During the film, you see the "brainless" scarecrow who feels he's very dumb, the "courage-less" lion who feels he lacks courage and the "heartless" tin man. But through their journey, you see the scarecrow, lion and and tin man display all their respective qualities that they feel they lack. At the end of the movie, during their encounter with the Wizard of Oz, he tells them that everything they had thought they lacked, they already had. This hammers home the two not-so-subtle meanings of the movie; Don't judge a book by it's cover and don't let anyone get you down and tell you what you can and can't do/are and aren't.

Author: 4 January 1999
Review_Url: I'm very young, still in my teens, but this movie has ALWAYS been my favorite. My room is adorned with posters, and memorabilia. When the AFI hosted the 100 greatest movies, I had feared that they would choose the more newer popular ones, with big names stars. I was, to put it bluntly, when "Oz" came in 6. And think about that! 6 out of the 100 narrowed down from over 50,000 thousand films ever made!!! I'm so happy. I hope they re-release the film in 1939 to celebrate the 100th anniversary! And it's only 40 years away! I'm psyched!!!!

Author: 30 January 1999
Review_Url: This ambitious musical works on every level, despite the fact that it detours quite a bit from the original book from L. Frank Baum. The story, as everyone already knows, centers around young Dorothy (age indistinct in the film) and her search for "home." During her wild adventure, she survives being carried by a tornado and dumped into a surrealistic place called Munchkinland. Here she meets both the Wicked Witch of the West and Glinda, the Good Witch of the North. Glinda, already knowing how Dorothy can return to Kansas, sends her on an arduous journey down the Yellow Brick Road, where she meets the Scarecrow, Tin Man, and Lion. Throughout the film, each character clearly shows that he or she already possesses what they covet most, but the realization does not come until the end of the film.

Author: 2 April 2004
Review: A long review of The Wizard of Oz for my Film As Historical Literature Class, covering the story and it's symbolism.(SPOILERS INSIDE!)
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz is a film best described as a metaphorical dream. It presents issues on two levels: those of a young girl, Dorothy Gale, a poor farm girl from Kansas who faces losing her dog to a nasty old woman, and those of a grander scale, like government evils and inefficiencies, and farming in arid Kansas. Under the guise of a children's book/movie, the story of The Wizard of Oz by L. Frank Baum is thought to be an allegory of the economic state of the Midwestern US and the Populist movement, of which Baum seemed to be a supporter, during the time that it was written. While the movie shows this, it was also changed to show more general ideals to reach a broader audience. Let us first look at the beginning of the film, and the characters. Starting on a dusty, windswept, desaturated Kansas farm, which seems to represent Dorothy's bland orphan life and presents the challenge that Dorothy is trapped in Boringsville unless she does something about it, the movie shows us the young, honest, pure, All-American girl Dorothy. Miss Gulch, a miserable crab of a woman, high up on the town's governmental ladder, is threatening canicide. Toto, Dorothy's dog and the only thing that brings joy to her otherwise black and white life, bit Miss Gulch, and now the old shrew is threatening Dorothy to take Toto away and have him killed. As Miss Gulch leaves with Toto, Toto escapes and finds his way back to Dorothy. The two then try to run away, but their plans are halted by a tornado. The next thing you know, Dorothy and Toto have just landed in Munchkin Land. Her house has landed on, and killed, The Wicked Witch of the East. The munchkins rejoice and Dorothy is rewarded with the witch's ruby slippers (which some believe represents "the 'inner spark' within all of us"), then sent on her way down the Yellow Brick Road to see the Wizard of Oz about getting back to Kansas. The Yellow Brick Road and the Ruby Slippers, which in the book are silver, are said to represent the gold and silver standards (monetary systems used during the 19th into the 20th centuries in which the paper bank notes were backed up by either gold or silver.). The main themes of the movie revolve around the idea of a better tomorrow, and there being "no place like home," and this Yellow Brick Road may also pose as a sort of "shining road to a better tomorrow/home." As the film progresses and Dorothy and Toto make their way down the Yellow Brick Road, they meet and befriend several characters. First to come along is the wise yet uneducated Scarecrow, representing the hard working hay-brained Kansas farmer who, despite his own view of himself, is smart, but lacks the education to prove it. Then comes the rust-frozen Tin Man, symbolic of the industry worker-compassionate, strong and sturdy but lacking a physical heart. Finally we meet the Cowardly Lion, king of the jungle, but afraid of everything. William Jennings Bryan, the thrice-defeated democratic presidential nominee who had many Populist views, such as bimetallism (having both gold and silver standards), is thought to be the model for the Lion. He was known as a great orator, but as they say, "his bark was greater than his bite," and Bryan had little power. Upon a more general view, the Lion may stand to represent the nobility of those who give up solely thinking about themselves and fight in defense of others and fight for what they know is right. The five go to Emerald City to ask the wizard for help, but they are sent away at first. Later the Wizard tries to intimidate them as they ask for their wishes to be granted. These scenes resemble the relationship between the higher government and citizens/lower government. The five are sent away at first because they could not possibly be important enough to speak to the Wizard of Oz, and when they finally do get to see Oz they come face to face with a giant, threatening, floating green head barking sternly at them. They only later discover, thanks to Toto, that Oz is just an insecure old man, with no real physical power, much like how government officials want us to think they are omnipotent deities. In one of the final scenes, the Witch is destroyed simply by being splashed with water. This is symbolic of the washing away of evil, but also, according to some sources, the Witch represents the dry Kansas soil. Her dousing can be seen as the taming of Kansas farmland. This point of view fits more with the book than the movie.

Author: 14 March 2001
Review: The best movie of all time
Review_Url: This has to be the best movie of all time, it is such a classic, i remember watching this movie when I was a little girl and just loving every note that Judy Garland sang and I still feel the same. Just watching with amazement on the years that have past by that this movie has entered in so many lives. The memorable lines "there's no place like home." and my favorite "Well, I - I think that it - it wasn't enough to just want to see Uncle Henry and Auntie Em - and it's that - if I ever go looking for my heart's desire again, I won't look any further than my own back yard. Because if it isn't there, I never really lost it to begin with! Is that right?" I hope that if you have not seen this movie that you will cause it will forever have a special place in your heart.

Author: 2 July 2001
Review_Url: One of the all time greats that never loses its appeal. The story of Dorothy Gale of Kansas and her spectacular trip to the land of Munchkins, good and bad witches, wizards, tin men, talking scarecrows and the cowardly lion is just as charming after the many times I have seen it as it was when I first saw it as a very small youth. One thing, no matter how many times you have seen this on TV, don't miss an opportunity to this classic on the big screen. You will be enthralled all over again.

Author: 5 October 2003
Review: The Best Movie of All Time
Review_Url: L. Frank Baum's beloved Classic the Wonderful Wizard of Oz is brought to life in this dazzling Musical! When 12year-old Dorothy is whisked away from her Kansas home by a Cyclone, she lands on the Wicked Witch of the East, in the Marvelous Land of Oz! Glinda, the Good Witch of the North gives her the magical Ruby Slippers & tells her that the only chance of getting home is to follow the Yellow Brick Road to the Emerald City to meet the Great & Powerful Wizard of Oz! Along the way she meets a Scarecrow who wants a brain, a Tin Man who longs for a heart, & a Cowardly Lion in desperate need of Courage! When they finally meet the great Oz, he tells  them they must kill the Witch of the West & bring him her broom-stick! see the movie to find out if Dorothy makes it home.

Author: 17 November 2021
Review: The beginning of the tale movies.
Review_Url: At the first glance, I searched for the trailer of that movie, and to be honest I wasn't surprised or excited enough. Nevertheless, after familiarizing myself with it I found out that this movie is a piece of art, in short, because there are many compelling reasons to count it so. It is advanced both from the plot side and the filming technique side. I suppose that it is the first old movie in which I faced the early beginning of filming tricks and techniques. So it was wonderful to feel the energy that comes from the movie itself.

Author: 19 January 2022
Review_Url: Calthough I get the feeling that everyone who wants to pick on the film or even openly hate it is doing so just to get attention for themselves. It's pure magic from start to finish. I could watch it a thousand times and experience pure, unadulterated joy every time. A cinematic classic, a Broadway musical brought to the big screen in color. Full of memorable songs and unforgettable scenes. The new 3D presentation brings the black and white scenes to life, while some of the color scenes, especially the wide shots, are too soft, but mostly everything is great.

Author: 22 June 2022
Review: So relevant to the current dystopia
Review_Url:
We've all been swept up by a tornado that has dropped us into a quest that we unconsciously initiated
by landing on the evil witch we carry within us, as well as the good. So of course, the magical slippers
go, not to the surviving witch, but to ourselves as we find our allies, the Tin man (love), the Scarecrow (wisdom)
and the Lion (power) in search of their manifestation and reclamation. And just as we have projected our safety into the Wizards outside of ourselves, like government and religion, they can only help by pointing to the fact that is we have always had the power to go home in the slippers of experience we wear and it is only by an act of compassion, Dorothy trying to put out the fire on the scarecrow and melting the witch instead, do we overcome
what we mistakenly believe imprisons us, just as we wake, like Dorothy, to find all the characters were just
impersonations of those who we find engaged with us in this life.

Author: 24 November 2002
Review_Url: Tonight I watched The Wizard of Oz the fifty-somethingith time during my fifty-somethingith years.  However, this is the first time I realized that this movie covered everything great and powerful in the film.  It had fantasy, mystery, horror, music and dancing, action, live animation, romance, morale, and special effects.  It showed rural life on the farm to big urban development such as in Emerald City or Munchkenland.  I was in awe and I always catch something I overlooked or under-appreciated in previous viewings.  I have seen this movie viewed through a young hippie-high-on-acid's eye but still enjoyed it as a clean-and-sober individual that I am today.  This movie is magical and realistic as it is classically contemporary.

Author: 12 January 2010
Review_Url: I certainly have enjoyed this movie for the fantasy it was for me over the years. Now, I see it completely differently. The Wizard is the Banker of London, the Rothchild family... Is there a difference ? The beast in the Bible given a real face ? I can see the banking system behind the curtain with all its magical treachery and deceptions. The paper money that has nothing to support it, no real value (as opposed to gold and silver), printed out of trees (money does grow from trees) and given a subjective value out of thin air (try to use Canadian dollars in the US).

Author: 8 August 2001
Review: I Love the Wizard of Oz!
Review_Url: I remember watching the Wizard of Oz as a child. It turned out to be my favorite movie of all time. I guess everyone wants to be Dorothy, and travel to a different place, and hope that your life could be different. I was also very afraid of the witch, but I loved the scare- crow, I think he was my favorite.  I have the movie and I watch it all the time. I never have tired of it, and now am passing it on to my grandchildren. Of all my childhood memories, waiting once a year for the Wizard of Oz to come on will be forever embedded in my memory. Remember after all, "There's no place like home".

Author: 17 March 2023
Review: How top Ruin a great story
Review_Url: When I was little, my dad read the book to my sister and both of them absolutely loved it. At the time I was too young to have the book read to me so I didn't know the story at all. Then some day a screening of this filmed took place at a local cinema and my dad and my sister couldn't wait to go there and took me there too. We watched the film and afterwards we felt terrible.there is no good redeeming factor about this film.the story of a beautifully written book is ruined by bad acting,annoying characters, weird props, and really really bead songs. I hated every second of this movie.after watching this movie I didn't want to read the book.the book is nowadays one of my favourites,but this film made me not want to read the book,because I had such a horrible memorie of the film. Why is this so highly rated? What can anyone who read the book seriously appreciate about this film? I don't get it ..

Author: 15 June 2006
Review: Young Dorothy and her dog Toto are caught up in a cyclone and land in the fantasy land of Oz, and begin a quest to find the Wizard to help her return home safely.
Review_Url: I had met Margaret Hamilton and knew her fairly well. Once, when she was in my apartment in New York for dinner, she disclosed some trivia facts regarding her role in "The Wizard of Oz." For one, she said she was absolutely terrified of having to disappear in a sulfur-based cloud of smoke. With split-second timing she had to find a very small square in the floor of the set and stand on it as the smoke issued around her while she was quickly lowered out of the scene. She had a terrible fear of missing the square and falling into the area below. To make matters worse, several takes were required and she was greatly relieved when it was over. A most gracious lady, she loved to talk about the film.

Author: 22 February 2006
Review_Url: I love this movie. I think that there is no movie before this or since this movie that can hold an audience young and old captivated. Everything about this movie is magical. The actors seem to be made for their part. The musical scores were wonderful and the theme was so simple and beautiful that anyone from all corners of the world can understand and identify with it. I've seen this movie many times over throughout the years and I'm 41 years old, and have watched it with my kids time and time again. A few years ago I took my wife to see this movie 'cause oddly enough she had never seen it and she too was captivated with it. I'll never tire of this movie and hope day to introduce my grandkids to it. So in my opinion this is the most magical and wonderful movie ever made.

It was a great laugh and visuals were fantastic (exept the flying evil monkeys). This is the kind of movie kids will love because of how cheerful it is and adults because of how half of the movie is just filled with repetitive dancing and stuff that wasnt important at all.

Author: 17 April 2005
Review_Url: One thing people need to keep in mind when they see this movie... it was made in 1939! It's going on seventy years old. People seem to expect so much from this film. It's not going to have ground-breaking special effects (by today's standards), or amazing computer generated sets/landscapes, or superb make-up/creatures. It is a simple film with a beautiful moral and, honestly, what more do you need? Judy Garland shines as Dorothy, coming through as very natural and honest. You believe her, and you believe in her quest. And her voice... it is so filled with emotion! There is a reason why this film has remained so prominent in our culture. It obviously did something right. If not, its songs wouldn't be murmured on the lips the lips of young children to this day. We wouldn't be seeing Oz merchandise in Targets and Wal-Marts all across the US. It wouldn't have a set air-date on huge television networks every year for going on fifty years. It is the ultimate American classic.

Author: 12 August 2005
Review: Wizzard of Oz is a thriller & classic!
Review_Url: I love the wizzard of oz it's a classic, fun, and great movie for all ages to enjoy! If anyone has not seen it I urge them to buy the updated version on DVD with behind the scenes and extra goodies for everyone to enjoy. Judy Garland was a wonderful actress, singer, and entertainer in all aspects of the entertainment industry. She was more than just another pretty face, or just an actress. She was a true entertainer in every aspect of the word. And continues to be an inspiration to many. The Wizzard of Oz is one of the world's most watched movies, and children of all ages and walks of life can enjoy the music, costumes, and comedy in this masterpiece. When it was released in 1939 the Wizzard of Oz was very cutting edge, and technologically advanced. I still enjoy watching it and if I ever do have children this will be a movie I will definitely pass on to them to savor! Thank you, R.I.P, Ms. Judy Garland! And remember pick up the DVD, you wont regret it!

Review_Url: I'm just doing this to fill out my profile.

Author: 4 February 2006
Review_Url: The Wizard of Oz, in my opinion, is, by far, the greatest movie of all time! I have never tired of the movie, and every time I see it I get something new out of it. When I watch it I get so into it that I feel like a part of me is in the movie along with them. I can remember as a child being so exited that it was going to be on T.V. and even though I was a rebellious teenager who was embarrassed to be hanging out with her parents, I would spend that one night of my own accord, watching The Wizard of Oz with my Mom, Dad, & brother. To me, it is the greatest story ever told! Everything about this movie is excellent, and it will never be duplicated nor will it ever be beat! If you haven't seen this movie, do yourself a favor.........see it & enjoy!!!!!
